Send this along to your creepiest friends! Share it with rich pets! Maybe you have a skeletal Dowager Countess in the family, surely she might have a ruby or two!

story:
Summary

The dog meat industry in South Korea is exceptionally cruel, is not regulated, and laws for slaughtering dogs inhumanely are not currently enforced. If you want evidence of just how cruel, see the short video shot by undercover CARE workers and used by The Korea Observer in an expose on former dog pets being killed by slaughter yards for consumption:http://goo.gl/025cID. 

The Korea Observer  intends to do a complete expose of the dog meat industry in South Korea. This includes engaging key political officials, dog farmers, legal officials, animal welfare groups, dog meat restaurant owners, police, judges, and who ever else is appropriate. Ideally, through a collective effort, we would like our investigative work to prompt a series of actions that lead to the end of dog meat farming and dog meat consumption in Korea. We will aim for this utopian goal but it may not be feasible in the short term. 

At the very least, The Korea Observer will interview officials and question why they do not impose licensing conditions and strict regulations on the dog meat industry to minimise the cruelty exhibited to dogs and former pets that are often tortured prior to being killed, fed the remains of killed dogs, kept in overcrowded, unsanitary conditions, and stacked on top of each other alive in small cages while being transported to market.  

We will show officials film we've captured, demonstrate that many Korean officials are ashamed of the industry, and use statistics to show that the world looks down on Korea due to their dog meat industry. 

UPDATE:- SOME OF THE WORK MAY BE ABLE TO BE DONE BY SKILLED VOLUNTEERS AND THEREFORE THE COST OF PRODUCTION WILL REDUCE CONSIDERABLY. In the interests of transparency: an animal activist and dog shelter owner in Korea has raised valid concerns about us purchasing equipment for this documentary and using some paid staff (i.e., not ALL volunteers). He also messaged several Facebook groups where we advertised the documentary strongly requesting no-one donate based on these concerns. I have addressed these concerns with him and offered the following:

"I agree that if volunteers come forward we’ll utilise them thus reducing the expense but we need some highly skilled technical staff who are unable to volunteer their time. Leftover funds will be apportioned and donated to those who have volunteered their time and to animal welfare groups in Korea."


UPDATE:


1. Koreandogs.org

A HUGE thank you to http://koreandogs.org/ who have donate $3500 for this documentary. We look forward to working with you now and in the future.

2. A massive THANK YOU to those who have donated funds so far. Please do not forget to share this campaign on Facebook and via email!!!!!!

If we don't get the 26K we will have to scale back what we were planning to do but we will still go ahead. The initial plan was to produce a professional documentary which would air in the US, Australia, and on various internet platforms. However, the TV networks only accept top quality documentaries shot (usually) with top quality equipment and professional editing. We will do our best to achieve what we can with whatever budget we get and hope that we get volunteers with technical skills and the use of equipment donated. [FYI - I used to have all the equipment required but was robbed and insurance did not cover us]. In summary, we will go ahead with the documentary if we only raise 10K, but it will be with less quality equipment, less technically skilled staff (i.e., volunteers), and it may not get as much exposure as we'd like it to]. We will still put 100% effort in and try our hardest!

3. Thank to CARE [http://www.careanimalrights.org/] for the use of visuals, your great report, and other resources. It is through information sharing and solidarity that we will prevail.  

4. Thank you to Rhett May [http://www.rhettmay.com/] for donating, with attribution and maintenance of copyright, his song Heaven or Hell.  

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cg2c1oipfWw

Rhett is a skilled artist with songs available on iTunes http://goo.gl/eb4wCP 

5. Thank you to HSI [http://www.hsi.org.au/] for providing some footage of meat dogs who have been rescued and re-homed in the U.S. This reduces the personal costs associated with flying to the U.S., sourcing interviews, and shooting those interviews ourselves. Thank you again!  


The Online Media Company – what we’ve done so far 

The Korea Observer is a relatively new media start-up that was inspired by Tae-hoon Lee after he witnessed the corruption and malpractice of media moguls in South Korea. “I was really ashamed of collecting pay checks for writing pro-government articles and paid content while working for Arirang TV and the Korea Times,” Lee Tae-hoon, publisher at the Korea Observer said. 

James Hyams joined as the deputy managing editor late 2014 following Lee Tae-hoon’s great work. He liked the notion of providing “A Voice for the Voiceless” and thinks that The Korea Observer can be the best English news service in South Korea with time, hard work, and enough resources. 

Since its inception in Feb 2013, The Korea Observer has reported news that would otherwise be ignored with the motto: “A Voice for the Voiceless.” The topics we’ve covered include the exclusion of specific races from jobs and bars, corporate malpractice and corruption, human rights abuses, LGBT rejection and discrimination, animal cruelty including the dog meat industry, child abuse in kindergartens, immigration and deportation issues, expat equality and rights, and so on. 

 Some notable publications include Boeing’s bribery of journalists with sexual entertainment, a Korean bar’s ban of Africans based on fears of Ebola, and the exposing the dog meat industry in South Korea to expats. We’ve also broken numerous stories, including human rights abuses by the Miss Asia Pacific World contest, Korea’s denial of entry to ‘pickup artist’ Julien Blanc, and an African American’s rejection for job interviews for being black in Korea. 

The Korea Observer was accepted into Google News early 2015. We are now competing with mainstream English speaking press in Korea on a zero dollar budget. Imagine what we could do with their massive budgets!  


The people behind the company 

Tae-hoon and James Hyams volunteer their time. Tae-hoon has not had a wage since February 2013. 

James is a social worker in Australia and this pays the bills. He works remotely for The Korea Observer. Without funding, we are severely limited to what we can do with The Korea Observer. 

Tae-hoon Lee

Lee Tae-hoon founded The Korea Observer in hopes of reporting news that would otherwise be ignored by the mainstream media in Korea. He quit Arirang TV after witnessing its senior staff officials embezzle money. Senior staff created accounts in false names and skimmed money from payments to contract workers. Lee later exposed those responsible in order to hold them accountable (http://bit.ly/1GK8Nfs). 

Lee left the Korea Times after witnessing the paper running advertorials without any mention of them being paid content and generating revenues under the excuse of helping multicultural children and others in need of help.

James Hyams 

James started working as a social worker in 2006 but realized that systemic and cognitive change is required to improve conditions for those with limited political and financial power. Despite knowing that journalism is withering and an income is not guaranteed, James went back to university and studied journalism, while still working as a social worker, with the hope that he could expose corporate and political power abuses, corruption, human rights abuse, animal cruelty cases, enhance opportunities for the less fortunate, and positively influence change within society. This is a utopian dream that is slowly being realized with The Korea Observer. 


Why we need you 

 Like many media start-ups, we are faced with the daily challenge of publishing articles without any resources. As noted above, some of our stories have been quality but some are b-grade pieces that we are not proud of. We have underutilized skills and a strong desire to regain our roots in investigative journalism but we need your help to really kickstart major investigations into topics that will be of international interest. With your support, we intend to be an active watchdog over Korea and international Korean companies such as Samsung, LG, Hyundai, Kia, Daewoo, Korean Air, Fila (clothing – yes it is Korea owned), Posco, SK, Lotte, and so on. 

Prior to investigating these large companies, we are asking for financial assistance to enable us to expose the dog meat industry in South Korea. As we know, dog meat is openly consumed in South Korea despite it being a developed, first world country. 

According to animal welfare group CARE the dog meat industry is massive. The Korean Statistics Information Service includes dog farming in the Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries Census. In 2010 they reported 892,820 dogs in 100,191 farms. All of these dogs, plus many dogs in shelters, pounds, and former pets will end up as food in restaurants or homes according to many animal welfare groups including CARE, HSI, Nami Kim, and other off-the-record groups. 

The above map comes from a CARE report.

The industry is not regulated and prosecutions for animal rights abuses are very rare. The only arrests for illegally hanging dogs, that we are aware of, occurred after The Korea Observer covered a story where there was photographic evidence of a Jindo dog being hung by the neck and killed by two migrants (http://goo.gl/1xh5Ck). The Korea Observer followed up and Animal rights activists reported this to the police who tracked down and arrested the main perpetrator (http://goo.gl/1Uy3mG). This matter is before the courts. Cases, such as this, can often be dismissed by judges without rational discussion. The onus is usually on the prosecutor to demonstrate that the dog was a companion dog (i.e., a pet) at the time of slaughter. 

We intend to explore why these laws are antiquated and behind the rest of the OECD countries. We intend to obtain footage of slaughterhouses hanging dogs and provide it to the police and judges for insight into why prosecution is so rare and follow up with law groups to determine the best action to create conditions where judges feel compelled to prosecute offenders. 

In CARE's full report on the dog industry, they demonstrate that pet auction houses (i.e., pet stores) also provide live dogs to slaughterhouses. A pet auction house in Cheonan holds around 200 dogs including Huskies, Labradors, Golden Retrievers, Cocker Spaniels, and Grey Hounds. “This is the biggest meat auction market in South Korea. Ninety percent of the sales here are for meat,” the owner said to CARE investigators. The Korea Observer will expose this link and the perpetrators. 

The above photo is a screenshot from a STOP IT video courtesy of CARE.

When transporting the dogs, it is common practice for farmers to squash as many live dogs into one cage as possible as shown in the STOP IT footage obtained from CARE. Most of the time dogs are stacked on top of each other and do not have enough room to stand up. “Many dogs die in the summer during transport,” one dog farmer said to investigators. The Korea Observer will follow these farmers to document how the dogs are mistreated and follow up with officials to determine if laws are being broken. If it is not illegal, we will question why! 

There are also unconfirmed claims that certain vets are providing companion dogs, scheduled to be put down, to slaughterhouses in exchange for remuneration. We will investigate these claims and expose those that cooperate in this practice. 

There are also locals and expats that covertly break into slaughterhouses, kill shelters, and dog farms that torture animals, and steal (rescue) the dogs prior to slaughter. These dogs are taken to the vet, given treatment, fed, given foster homes, and then re-homed locally or internationally. The activists engaged in these practices have devoted their lifesavings to saving and re-homing suffering dogs bound for slaughter. Many have sold all their assets, live a very basic life with only bare essentials to survive, and put all of their resources into saving dogs. Their stories need to be told! They also courier some of these dogs over the US for adoption establishing an international dog saving network, which we also intend to visually document. 

The Korea Observer has been communicating with dog welfare activists since late 2014 to understand the industry and how best to bring about change. We intend to investigate this industry in its entirety but require funds to do that. The final product will be written stories with photographs and a gonzo-style documentary. James will also write an eBook about the investigation. 


What the funds will specifically be used for

1. Following the dog meat trail from Jeju Island to the mainland. Dogs are transported to the South Korean peninsula from famous Jeju Island twice a week despite representatives of the Port Development Division in Jeju saying, “Dogs are never transported to the mainland by boat.” This is the most disturbing method of transportation. We want to document it in full and interview the transporter. Many dogs die during this transportation route. 

$400 including ~ $200 for one way flights to jeju island for two and car hire from the main land to follow the truck with the dogs etc.

2. Follow the dog meat trail from the Vet/pet shelter/dog auction as well as abusive farms to market and/or dog slaughterhouse. This requires hundreds of hours of stakeouts and is very resource intensive. We will not be able to do this alone and will have to hire other skilled investigators to do this. 

~ $3000 for 2 investigators to work for a week each including all of their expenses. They will also film during these visits. 

UPDATE:- THIS MAY BE ABLE TO BE DONE BY SKILLED VOLUNTEERS AND THEREFORE REDUCE THE EXPENSE CONSIDERABLY.

3. Independently conduct covert surveillance of dog meat markets, restaurants, farms, and slaughterhouses. Conduct interviews with relevant authorities, edit footage, store footage, and write articles. ~ $6,000 (400 hours @$15 per hour)

UPDATE:- SOME OF THIS MAY BE ABLE TO BE DONE BY SKILLED VOLUNTEERS AND THEREFORE REDUCE THE EXPENSE CONSIDERABLY.

4. Launch a survey on the opinions of outsiders on the dog meat industry in Korea. This survey will need 1,000 participants and be done using random sampling. The exact methodology would need to be worked out and we’d engage academic researchers and an independent third party in order to maintain objectivity.

~$2,000 if done on a budget and using volunteers to assist in gather the data. Of course, we will try to get an academic to drive this survey for free but that is unlikely.

5. Forge working relationships with key stakeholders, which are usually done by meeting them in person and having meals or drinks together. We will NOT pay directly for information (unless it is a prescribed photocopying fee or similar) as this often results in sources giving information they think you want to hear rather than the truth. This includes digging for dirt on specific members of the Korean police, government, judges, food and livestock authorities, and other appropriate authorities role in regulating (or not regulating) cruelty to animals and how they are connected. We will need to forge working relationships with the appropriate police, officials, and informants. We, however, would need to pick up the tab if those stakeholders are in financial difficulties or feel uncomfortable sharing the bills. It is a Korean custom that an older person or those who made the invitation (which would be us) to pick up the tab.

~$500 if done on a budget. For the record, I don’t like this system, but it is effective and saves time and money in the long term.

6. Printing costs for posters and information on the dog meat industry as well as blank DVDs and cases.  

~$350++ 

7. Travel to and from the main dog farm and areas. Transport is relatively cheap in Korea but we’d need to do regular travel and sometimes hire a van. 

 ~$1,200. (2 reporters on the move daily at around $10 per day each plus the hire of a van for a week when required ~ $700 and the occasional taxi as uber has not been shut down in Korea).

8. Accommodation and food in other areas for two reporters while investigating. We will stay at dodgy hotels that cost around $40-$60 per night or even try to stay for free with contacts if we can (anything to keep costs down). We will intermittently stay at backpackers as well as these can be great sources of information. 

~ $1,100 for 14 nights in a shared room with basic meals et cetera. 

9. Film translation and subtitle development.

~$600 if $20 per hour for subtitle translation (when editing film).

10. Equipment purchase: Although we have our own equipment that we will use, we require some specific cameras (that we don’t have) and an FPV drone to gather evidence. We also need at least 5 eye-fi memory cards ($160 each) – we expect to encounter resistance during our investigations and we need a system where whatever we film or photograph immediately goes on the internet (i.e., if our cameras are destroyed, stolen, or seized by the police their contents will already be uploading to the internet). We also need specialist sound equipment. 

- $5,300 composed of: cameras and drone with extra batteries and gimbal $3,700; Eye-fi cards $800; Sound equipment $800

UPDATE:- WE MAY BE ABLE TO HIRE SOME EQUIPMENT OR HAVE ITS USE DONATED THEREFORE CUTTING THE EXPENSE CONSIDERABLY.

11. Legal protection. We need to hire a lawyer to mitigate against any lawsuits that arise from this story. 

 ~ $2,500 if we cannot get someone to assist pro bono.

12. Scientific tests to determine the bacteria and antibiotic levels present in dogs and some vet bills (at material cost).  

 ~$1,300 

TOTAL =$24,250 plus fees of 9%+1% degree of error ($2,425)

Grand total =$26,675


What else will we do?

We’ve already exposed that slaughterhouses do not differentiate between meat dogs and pet dogs (http://www.koreaobserver.com/former-pets-slaughtered-for-dog-meat-across-korea-25566). NGO Coexistence for Animal Rights on Earth also shattered this myth photographing several pet breed dogs in slaughterhouses with those bred for meat. 

WARNING - VIDEO EXTREMELY GRAPHIC & SHOWS DOGS BEING KILLED


The next step to this is exploring the number of pets that are taken to animal shelters and how many are put down. We expect this number will be massive and try to interview vets who acknowledge that they sell/donate former pets to the dog slaughterhouses/auctions to avoid euthanising them.

Some Koreans also argue that dog meat is consumed as a traditional cultural practice – we will explore this and determine its validity. It is popular opinion that Korean dog meat is good for your health – we will also investigate this using food and bacteria analytical reports as well as interviews with the relevant food associations.

There are also dog tonics and medicines produced using dog as an ingredient – we will identify if this is done lawfully and track those down who violate those laws. We will also test the efficacy of these tonics and invite comments from doctors and/or food scientists.

We will also interview restaurant owners to determine if they know how the dogs they are using as food are slaughtered and get their reactions. It is highly probable that most know how the dogs are killed and do not care. This then reinforces the need for the industry to be regulated, which would drive the prices of the meat up and less people would consume it. This would be the first step to reducing consumption and getting the industry banned.

We also intend to expose the interconnection between some dog farms and dog shelters. Animal activists have come across evidence that reveals a number of dog shelter owners also run dog farms. This means that dogs rescued from other meat farms, the streets, pounds, or surrendered to them end up back in dog farms and will be killed for consumption. If we can prove this then it gives a strong argument that shelters and dog farms need to be licensed on a national register and regulated at the very least.

When we come across dog farms that are particularly cruel, we will inform the relevant authorities for follow up and pressure them to ensure they follow up. 


Risks and challenges

1. Although we will try not to be noticed by corrupt authorities, they are likely to pressure us to drop the documentary and threaten us with illegal incarceration. This would only further enhance the quality of the documentary and give international media exposure to a very cruel industry. If this occurs, we will engage other media, animal rights, human rights, and legal rights groups from our contact network to expose the South Korean legal industry for what it is. The project will always go on!

2. There is a risk that our technical equipment and memory cards are stolen or smashed by perpetrators. That is why we will use eye-fi memory cards that auto upload to a phone or laptop with dropbox. Thus footage can never be stolen or destroyed even if our equipment is ceased or destroyed.

3. Government officials refuse to engage with us or be interviewed. We will be persistent and insistent. Where necessary, we will send gifts (as outlined in the costing summary) or forge strategic partnerships to obtain footage/documents via other non-traditional (or covert) means. If this in ineffective, we will do stakeouts try to engage the official while they are walking to their car, shopping, drinking at a bar, or even request a lady (a hostess) at a business club (a place where Korean businessmen go to drink and host meetings with female escorts) ask for the information from them.

4. To complete this project well it will take at least 3 months but more likely be achieved around the 6 month mark. This timeframe factors in several risks including the possibility of encountering hostility from key stakeholders. This is not the first time Tae-hoon and James have encountered these sorts of issues and our experience as journalists provides us with the competency to use this hostility to our advantage.

5. We may get hacked and have our news site vandalised, which is probably the most likely risk. We have already been hacked twice but we have improved security. We have a backup of our site so that if our website is destroyed or taken offline we can restore it without major difficulties. Also, we will store our research on back-up hard drives to ensure we always have a master copy.
story_txt:
Summary
The dog meat industry in South Korea is
exceptionally cruel, is not regulated, and laws for slaughtering dogs
inhumanely are not currently enforced. If you want evidence of just how cruel,
see the short video shot by undercover CARE workers and used by The Korea
Observer in an expose on former dog pets being killed by slaughter yards for
consumption:http://goo.gl/025cID. 
The Korea Observer  intends to do a complete expose of the dog meat
industry in South Korea. This includes engaging key political officials, dog
farmers, legal officials, animal welfare groups, dog meat restaurant owners,
police, judges, and who ever else is appropriate. Ideally, through a collective
effort, we would like our investigative work to prompt a series of actions that
lead to the end of dog meat farming and dog meat consumption in Korea. We will
aim for this utopian goal but it may not be feasible in the short term. 
At
the very least, The Korea Observer will interview officials and question why
they do not impose licensing conditions and strict regulations on the dog meat
industry to minimise the cruelty exhibited to dogs and former pets that are
often tortured prior to being killed, fed the remains of killed dogs, kept in
overcrowded, unsanitary conditions, and stacked on top of each other alive in
small cages while being transported to market.  
We
will show officials film we've captured, demonstrate that many Korean officials
are ashamed of the industry, and use statistics to show that the world looks
down on Korea due to their dog meat industry. UPDATE:- SOME OF THE WORK MAY BE ABLE TO BE DONE BY SKILLED VOLUNTEERS AND THEREFORE THE COST OF PRODUCTION WILL REDUCE CONSIDERABLY. In the interests of transparency: an animal activist and dog shelter owner in Korea has raised valid concerns about us purchasing equipment for this documentary and using some paid staff (i.e., not ALL volunteers). He also messaged several Facebook groups where we advertised the documentary strongly requesting no-one donate based on these concerns. I have addressed these concerns with him and offered the following:"I agree that if volunteers come forward we’ll utilise them thus reducing the expense but we need some highly skilled technical staff who are unable to volunteer their time. Leftover funds will be apportioned and donated to those who have volunteered their time and to animal welfare groups in Korea."UPDATE:1. Koreandogs.orgA HUGE thank you to http://koreandogs.org/ who have donate $3500 for this documentary. We look forward to working with you now and in the future.2. A massive THANK YOU to those who have donated funds so far. Please do not forget to share this campaign on Facebook and via email!!!!!!If we don't get the 26K we will have to scale back what we were planning to do but we will still go ahead. The initial plan was to produce a professional documentary which would air in the US, Australia, and on various internet platforms. However, the TV networks only accept top quality documentaries shot (usually) with top quality equipment and professional editing. We will do our best to achieve what we can with whatever budget we get and hope that we get volunteers with technical skills and the use of equipment donated. [FYI - I used to have all the equipment required but was robbed and insurance did not cover us]. In summary, we will go ahead with the documentary if we only raise 10K, but it will be with less quality equipment, less technically skilled staff (i.e., volunteers), and it may not get as much exposure as we'd like it to].  We will still put 100% effort in and try our hardest!3. Thank to CARE [http://www.careanimalrights.org/] for the use of visuals, your great report, and other resources. It is through information sharing and solidarity that we will prevail.  4. Thank you to Rhett May [http://www.rhettmay.com/] for donating, with attribution and maintenance of copyright, his song Heaven or Hell.  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cg2c1oipfWwRhett is a skilled artist with songs available on iTunes http://goo.gl/eb4wCP 5. Thank you to HSI [http://www.hsi.org.au/] for providing some footage of meat dogs who have been rescued and re-homed in the U.S. This reduces the personal costs associated with flying to the U.S., sourcing interviews, and shooting those interviews ourselves. Thank you again!  
The Online Media Company – what we’ve done so far 
The
Korea Observer is a relatively new media start-up that was inspired by Tae-hoon
Lee after he witnessed the corruption and malpractice of media moguls in South
Korea. “I was really ashamed of collecting pay checks for writing pro-government
articles and paid content while working for Arirang TV and the Korea Times,”
Lee Tae-hoon, publisher at the Korea Observer said. 
James
Hyams joined as the deputy managing editor late 2014 following Lee Tae-hoon’s
great work. He liked the notion of providing “A Voice for the Voiceless” and
thinks that The Korea Observer can be the best English news service in South
Korea with time, hard work, and enough resources. 
Since
its inception in Feb 2013, The Korea Observer has reported news that would
otherwise be ignored with the motto: “A Voice for the Voiceless.” The topics
we’ve covered include the exclusion of specific races from jobs and bars,
corporate malpractice and corruption, human rights abuses, LGBT rejection and
discrimination, animal cruelty including the dog meat industry, child abuse in
kindergartens, immigration and deportation issues, expat equality and rights,
and so on. 
 Some
notable publications include Boeing’s bribery of journalists with sexual
entertainment, a Korean bar’s ban of Africans based on fears of Ebola, and the
exposing the dog meat industry in South Korea to expats. We’ve also broken
numerous stories, including human rights abuses by the Miss Asia Pacific World
contest, Korea’s denial of entry to ‘pickup artist’ Julien Blanc, and an
African American’s rejection for job interviews for being black in Korea. 
The
Korea Observer was accepted into Google News early 2015. We are now competing
with mainstream English speaking press in Korea on a zero dollar budget.
Imagine what we could do with their massive budgets!  

The
people behind the company 
Tae-hoon
and James Hyams volunteer their time. Tae-hoon has not had a wage since
February 2013. 
James
is a social worker in Australia and this pays the bills. He works remotely for
The Korea Observer. Without funding, we are severely limited to what we can do
with The Korea Observer. 
Tae-hoon Lee
Lee Tae-hoon founded The Korea Observer in
hopes of reporting news that would otherwise be ignored by the mainstream media
in Korea. He quit Arirang TV after witnessing its senior staff officials
embezzle money. Senior staff created accounts in false names and skimmed money
from payments to contract workers. Lee later exposed those responsible in order
to hold them accountable (http://bit.ly/1GK8Nfs). 
Lee
left the Korea Times after witnessing the paper running advertorials without
any mention of them being paid content and generating revenues under the excuse
of helping multicultural children and others in need of help.
James Hyams 
James
started working as a social worker in 2006 but realized that systemic and
cognitive change is required to improve conditions for those with limited
political and financial power. Despite knowing that journalism is withering and
an income is not guaranteed, James went back to university and studied
journalism, while still working as a social worker, with the hope that he could
expose corporate and political power abuses, corruption, human rights abuse,
animal cruelty cases, enhance opportunities for the less fortunate, and
positively influence change within society. This is a utopian dream that is
slowly being realized with The Korea Observer. 

Why we
need you 
 Like
many media start-ups, we are faced with the daily challenge of publishing
articles without any resources. As noted above, some of our stories have been
quality but some are b-grade pieces that we are not proud of. We have
underutilized skills and a strong desire to regain our roots in investigative
journalism but we need your help to really kickstart major investigations into
topics that will be of international interest. With your support, we intend to
be an active watchdog over Korea and international Korean companies such as
Samsung, LG, Hyundai, Kia, Daewoo, Korean Air, Fila (clothing – yes it is Korea
owned), Posco, SK, Lotte, and so on. 
Prior
to investigating these large companies, we are asking for financial assistance
to enable us to expose the dog meat industry in South Korea. As we know, dog
meat is openly consumed in South Korea despite it being a developed, first
world country. According to animal welfare group CARE the
dog meat industry is massive. The Korean Statistics Information Service
includes dog farming in the Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries Census. In 2010
they reported 892,820 dogs in 100,191 farms. All of these dogs, plus many dogs
in shelters, pounds, and former pets will end up as food in restaurants or
homes according to many animal welfare groups including CARE, HSI, Nami Kim, and other off-the-record groups. 

The above map comes from a CARE report.The industry is not regulated and prosecutions
for animal rights abuses are very rare. The only arrests for illegally hanging
dogs, that we are aware of, occurred after The Korea Observer covered a story
where there was photographic evidence of a Jindo dog being hung by the neck and
killed by two migrants (http://goo.gl/1xh5Ck). The
Korea Observer followed up and Animal rights activists reported this to the
police who tracked down and arrested the main perpetrator (http://goo.gl/1Uy3mG). This matter is before the
courts. Cases, such as this, can often be dismissed by judges without rational
discussion. The onus is usually on the prosecutor to demonstrate that the dog
was a companion dog (i.e., a pet) at the time of slaughter. We
intend to explore why these laws are antiquated and behind the rest of the OECD
countries. We intend to obtain footage of slaughterhouses hanging dogs and
provide it to the police and judges for insight into why prosecution is so rare
and follow up with law groups to determine the best action to create conditions
where judges feel compelled to prosecute offenders. 
In CARE's full report on the dog industry, they demonstrate that pet auction houses (i.e.,
pet stores) also provide live dogs to slaughterhouses. A pet auction house in
Cheonan holds around 200 dogs including Huskies, Labradors, Golden Retrievers,
Cocker Spaniels, and Grey Hounds. “This is the biggest meat auction market in
South Korea. Ninety percent of the sales here are for meat,” the owner said to CARE investigators.
The Korea Observer will expose this link and the perpetrators. 
The above photo is a screenshot from a STOP IT video courtesy of CARE.When
transporting the dogs, it is common practice for farmers to squash as many live
dogs into one cage as possible as shown in the STOP IT footage obtained from CARE. Most of the time dogs are stacked on top of
each other and do not have enough room to stand up. “Many dogs die in the
summer during transport,” one dog farmer said to investigators. The Korea Observer will follow these farmers to
document how the dogs are mistreated and follow up with officials to determine
if laws are being broken. If it is not illegal, we will question why! 
There
are also unconfirmed claims that certain vets are providing companion dogs,
scheduled to be put down, to slaughterhouses in exchange for remuneration. We
will investigate these claims and expose those that cooperate in this practice. 
There
are also locals and expats that covertly break into slaughterhouses, kill
shelters, and dog farms that torture animals, and steal (rescue) the dogs prior to
slaughter. These dogs are taken to the vet, given treatment, fed, given foster
homes, and then re-homed locally or internationally. The activists engaged in
these practices have devoted their lifesavings to saving and re-homing
suffering dogs bound for slaughter. Many have sold all their assets, live a
very basic life with only bare essentials to survive, and put all of their
resources into saving dogs. Their stories need to be told! They also courier
some of these dogs over the US for adoption establishing an international dog
saving network, which we also intend to visually document. 
The
Korea Observer has been communicating with dog welfare activists since late
2014 to understand the industry and how best to bring about change. We intend
to investigate this industry in its entirety but require funds to do that. The
final product will be written stories with photographs and a gonzo-style
documentary. James will also write an eBook about the investigation. 
What the funds will
specifically be used for
1. Following the dog meat
trail from Jeju Island to the mainland. Dogs are transported to the South
Korean peninsula from famous Jeju Island twice a week despite representatives
of the Port Development Division in Jeju saying, “Dogs are never transported to
the mainland by boat.” This is the most disturbing method of transportation. We
want to document it in full and interview the transporter. Many dogs die during
this transportation route. 
$400
including ~ $200 for one way flights to jeju island for two and car hire from
the main land to follow the truck with the dogs etc.
2. Follow the dog meat trail
from the Vet/pet shelter/dog auction as well as abusive farms to market and/or
dog slaughterhouse. This requires hundreds of hours of stakeouts and is very
resource intensive. We will not be able to do this alone and will have to hire
other skilled investigators to do this. 
~
$3000 for 2 investigators to work for a week each including all of their
expenses. They will also film during these visits. UPDATE:- THIS MAY BE ABLE TO BE DONE BY SKILLED VOLUNTEERS AND THEREFORE REDUCE THE EXPENSE CONSIDERABLY.
3. Independently conduct
covert surveillance of dog meat markets, restaurants, farms, and
slaughterhouses. Conduct interviews with relevant authorities, edit footage,
store footage, and write articles. ~ $6,000 (400 hours @$15 per hour)UPDATE:- SOME OF THIS MAY BE ABLE TO BE DONE BY SKILLED VOLUNTEERS AND THEREFORE REDUCE THE EXPENSE CONSIDERABLY.4. Launch a survey on the
opinions of outsiders on the dog meat industry in Korea. This survey will need
1,000 participants and be done using random sampling. The exact methodology
would need to be worked out and we’d engage academic researchers and an
independent third party in order to maintain objectivity.
~$2,000
if done on a budget and using volunteers to assist in gather the data. Of
course, we will try to get an academic to drive this survey for free but that
is unlikely.
5. Forge working relationships
with key stakeholders, which are usually done by meeting them in person and
having meals or drinks together. We will NOT pay directly for information
(unless it is a prescribed photocopying fee or similar) as this often results in
sources giving information they think you want to hear rather than the truth.
This includes digging for dirt on specific members of the Korean police,
government, judges, food and livestock authorities, and other appropriate
authorities role in regulating (or not regulating) cruelty to animals and how
they are connected. We will need to forge working relationships with the
appropriate police, officials, and informants. We, however, would need to
pick up the tab if those stakeholders are in financial difficulties or feel
uncomfortable sharing the bills. It is a Korean custom that an older person or
those who made the invitation (which would be us) to pick up the tab.
~$500
if done on a budget. For the record, I don’t like this system, but it is
effective and saves time and money in the long term.
6. Printing costs for
posters and information on the dog meat industry as well as blank DVDs and
cases.  
~$350++ 
7. Travel to and from the
main dog farm and areas. Transport is relatively cheap in Korea but we’d need
to do regular travel and sometimes hire a van. 
 ~$1,200.
(2 reporters on the move daily at around $10 per day each plus the hire of a
van for a week when required ~ $700 and the occasional taxi as uber has
not been shut down in Korea).
8. Accommodation and food in
other areas for two reporters while investigating. We will stay at dodgy hotels
that cost around $40-$60 per night or even try to stay for free with contacts
if we can (anything to keep costs down). We will intermittently stay at
backpackers as well as these can be great sources of information. 
~
$1,100 for 14 nights in a shared room with basic meals et cetera. 
9. Film translation and
subtitle development.
~$600
if $20 per hour for subtitle translation (when editing film).
10. Equipment purchase:
Although we have our own equipment that we will use, we require some specific
cameras (that we don’t have) and an FPV drone to gather evidence. We also need
at least 5 eye-fi memory cards ($160 each) – we expect to encounter resistance
during our investigations and we need a system where whatever we film or
photograph immediately goes on the internet (i.e., if our cameras are
destroyed, stolen, or seized by the police their contents will already be
uploading to the internet). We also need specialist sound equipment. 
-
$5,300 composed of: cameras and drone with extra batteries and gimbal $3,700;
Eye-fi cards $800; Sound equipment $800UPDATE:- WE MAY BE ABLE TO HIRE SOME EQUIPMENT OR HAVE ITS USE DONATED THEREFORE CUTTING THE EXPENSE CONSIDERABLY.
11. Legal protection. We need
to hire a lawyer to mitigate against any lawsuits that arise from this
story. 
 ~
$2,500 if we cannot get someone to assist pro bono.12. Scientific tests to determine the bacteria and antibiotic levels present in dogs and some vet bills (at material cost).  
 ~$1,300 
TOTAL =$24,250 plus fees of 9%+1% degree of error ($2,425)
Grand total =$26,675
What else will we do?
We’ve already exposed that slaughterhouses do
not differentiate between meat dogs and pet dogs (http://www.koreaobserver.com/former-pets-slaughtered-for-dog-meat-across-korea-25566).
NGO Coexistence for Animal Rights on Earth also shattered this myth
photographing several pet breed dogs in slaughterhouses with those bred for
meat. WARNING - VIDEO EXTREMELY GRAPHIC & SHOWS DOGS BEING KILLED
The
next step to this is exploring the number of pets that are taken to animal
shelters and how many are put down. We expect this number will be massive and
try to interview vets who acknowledge that they sell/donate former pets to the
dog slaughterhouses/auctions to avoid euthanising them.
Some
Koreans also argue that dog meat is consumed as a traditional cultural practice
– we will explore this and determine its validity. It is popular opinion that
Korean dog meat is good for your health – we will also investigate this using
food and bacteria analytical reports as well as interviews with the relevant
food associations.
There
are also dog tonics and medicines produced using dog as an ingredient – we will
identify if this is done lawfully and track those down who violate those laws.
We will also test the efficacy of these tonics and invite comments from doctors
and/or food scientists.
We
will also interview restaurant owners to determine if they know how the dogs
they are using as food are slaughtered and get their reactions. It is highly
probable that most know how the dogs are killed and do not care. This then
reinforces the need for the industry to be regulated, which would drive the
prices of the meat up and less people would consume it. This would be the first
step to reducing consumption and getting the industry banned.
We
also intend to expose the interconnection between some dog farms and dog
shelters. Animal activists have come across evidence that reveals a number of
dog shelter owners also run dog farms. This means that dogs rescued from other
meat farms, the streets, pounds, or surrendered to them end up back in dog
farms and will be killed for consumption. If we can prove this then it gives a
strong argument that shelters and dog farms need to be licensed on a national
register and regulated at the very least.When we come across dog farms that are particularly cruel, we will inform the relevant authorities for follow up and pressure them to ensure they follow up. 
Risks
and challenges
1. Although we will try not to be noticed by corrupt authorities, they are likely to pressure us to drop the documentary and threaten us with illegal incarceration. This would only further enhance the quality of the documentary
and give international media exposure to a very cruel industry. If this occurs,
we will engage other media, animal rights, human rights, and legal rights groups from our
contact network to expose the South Korean legal industry for what it is. The
project will always go on!
2.
There is a risk that our technical equipment and memory cards are stolen or
smashed by perpetrators. That is why we will use eye-fi memory cards that auto
upload to a phone or laptop with dropbox. Thus footage can never be stolen or
destroyed even if our equipment is ceased or destroyed.
3.
Government officials refuse to engage with us or be interviewed. We will be
persistent and insistent. Where necessary, we will send gifts (as outlined in
the costing summary) or forge strategic partnerships to obtain
footage/documents via other non-traditional (or covert) means. If this in
ineffective, we will do stakeouts try to engage the official while they are
walking to their car, shopping, drinking at a bar, or even request a lady (a
hostess) at a business club (a place where Korean businessmen go to drink and
host meetings with female escorts) ask for the information from them.
4.
To complete this project well it will take at least 3 months but more likely be
achieved around the 6 month mark. This timeframe factors in several risks
including the possibility of encountering hostility from key stakeholders. This
is not the first time Tae-hoon and James have encountered these sorts of issues
and our experience as journalists provides us with the competency to use this
hostility to our advantage.
5.
We may get hacked and have our news site vandalised, which is probably the most
likely risk. We have already been hacked twice but we have improved security.
We have a backup of our site so that if our website is destroyed or taken
offline we can restore it without major difficulties. Also, we will store our research
on back-up hard drives to ensure we always have a master copy.

story:
Pitch Deck

 

Why

So y'all know overdraft fees, right...? And how they'll literally drain your account and get you even more negative and make it impossible to get out of .....? Yeah. So one day, I got really mad about that, after over $300 in fees in the span of a week due to an issue with PayPal. My bank was being less than helpful, and after calling every day for hours a day for 3 weeks, I was sick of it. It just kept getting worse and worse and worse and then the nonsufficient fund (NSF) fees started and blah blah blah I wrote a short film about it. Cuz I can. And Ari's Executive Producer. 

Overdraft and NSF fees literally take advantage of poor people. I was negative for over a month str8 going back and forth with my bank dealing with all these fees, and then even over 2 years later, still dealing with the consequences of managing to get so many fees reversed. Overdraft fees are around $35 flat no matter what (at least for my bank), even if you're just -$7. And then NSF fees literally charge you for not having money.......... The more fees you get, the harder it is to not be negative later, which just makes it more likely to get even more fees and more fees and more fees and... It sucks. So. Tadah! 

Oh and there's muckduck involved !!! cuz it's a movie. Anyways let's get rid of fees shalln't we? Fuck Capitalism. Viva la getting rid of banking CEOs. Stop fucking taking advantage of poor people.

 

What We Need & What You Get

We need money! duh... We are about people and want our very talented cast and crew to be paid fairly for their work, which happens far less often than you'd expect in this industry......... (Not to mention sound and color and editing make or break a film and we want happy post-production people)

This budget is great and all, but we have some incredible, talented humans working on this project, and if we can raise more than the budget we can pay them more and make something even more magical (you know, the triangle, fast/good/cheap?) After everyone gets paid more, cuz, yes, there is a limit, the rest of it will go to future films from AnGST Films and Purple Hair Person Productions. 

What you get is the movie! I mean, a lot of other cool shit too, but, the movie, that's kinda the point of the campaign. We want to make a movie, a short film. Tadah!

 

The Impact

Capitalism sucks, and we want to yell at the banks and government without, ya know, actually doing anything illegal...

Bank fees exist to take money from people who don't have it, the more fees you get the less money you have, and the less money you have the more you have to pay. (it's like the chicken and the egg)

Fun fact (actually, really really sad fact) this is impacting Millennials/Zillennials/Gen Z wayyyy more than any other generation previously, so this has to do with you too

We wanna start a conversation. Everyone, well not everyone, but you know, deals with these fees and we never talk about it. If we talk about it, maybe they will FUCKINNNN change.......

 

Risks & Challenges

Making a film is expensive, paying a crew is expensive, ESPECIALLY post production (though that's for REALLY good reason, ask us about our horror stories sometime), marketing is expensive...and food is expensive (lbr that is the most important part anyway, again, we ARE Jews.)

We want the film to look good, sound good, be something we can be proud of (again, ask about our horror stories), and we want to share it with as many people as we can ✨ ✨ 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Share this! Make posts about our film! Tell all your friends! Bug your parents for money (yes, including you Millennials). Tell your film producer uncle to fund us.... ✨ ✨ this isn't a joke✨ ✨ 

Get creative, anything works, just make sure to tag us @daniellesilverstone, @ariella.elm, and @overdraftfilm, we'll share it on the film's socials!

We love y'all! Let's make movie magic! ✨ ✨

So y'all know overdraft fees, right...? And how they'll literally drain your account and get you even more negative and make it impossible to get out of .....? Yeah. What you get is the movie! I mean, a lot of other cool shit too, but, the movie, that's kinda the point of the campaign. We want to make a movie, a short film. Tadah!
 

The Impact
Capitalism sucks, and we want to yell at the banks and government without, ya know, actually doing anything illegal...
Bank fees exist to take money from people who don't have it, the more fees you get the less money you have, and the less money you have the more you have to pay. (it's like the chicken and the egg)
Fun fact (actually, really really sad fact) this is impacting Millennials/Zillennials/Gen Z wayyyy more than any other generation previously, so this has to do with you too
We wanna start a conversation. Everyone, well not everyone, but you know, deals with these fees and we never talk about it. If we talk about it, maybe they will FUCKINNNN change.......
 

Risks & Challenges
Making a film is expensive, paying a crew is expensive, ESPECIALLY post production (though that's for REALLY good reason, ask us about our horror stories sometime), marketing is expensive...and food is expensive (lbr that is the most important part anyway, again, we ARE Jews.)
We want the film to look good, sound good, be something we can be proud of (again, ask about our horror stories), and we want to share it with as many people as we can ✨ ✨ 
 

Other Ways You Can Help
Share this! Make posts about our film! Tell all your friends! Bug your parents for money (yes, including you Millennials). Tell your film producer uncle to fund us.... ✨ ✨ this isn't a joke✨ ✨ 
Get creative, anything works, just make sure to tag us @daniellesilverstone, @ariella.elm, and @overdraftfilm, we'll share it on the film's socials!
We love y'all! Let's make movie magic! ✨ ✨

story:
More Than A Shadow is a short horror comedy film, from the brain of Writer and Director Charley Gaidoni.

Amelia is a house renovator, who has been hired to rejuvenate the old Bythesea House. However, after an encounter with an old Baron who still haunts the house during the night, she decides to put an end to his spooky antics so she can finish the job. Though she succeeds, she feels bad for casting the poltergeist to the attic, so goes to apologise and ends up becoming friends with him.

What we’re aiming to receive from fundraising is enough money to help More Than A Shadow truly shine! We have some money put towards the film already – though most of it has already gone on securing our fabulous location – but to really make it stand out, we’re asking for the generosity of you and others to help us add some extra flare to the production. And we’ll make sure to make it worth your while too!

The ultimate goal would be to get this film into festivals and to potentially turn it into a full feature-length film, with this film acting as almost a ‘teaser’ for more exciting ideas and stories to come. So, the better More Than A Shadow looks as a short film, the more likely it is to grow into something bigger and better.

If you have any questions about the perks or anything else about the campaign, please check the Frequently Asked Questions tab or feel free to leave a comment with feedback or further questions you'd like answered!

 

We’re asking for £1200 to help the film get to be the best it can be. We have already raised £1200 externally, which is currently going towards the locations and paying our brilliant actors. However, we want to make sure that everything else about the film shines bright as well! Your money will be going towards:

  • Extra funds for the actors’ fantastic work, helping us in case we need to film an extra day or two.
  • Paying the fee for our incredible voice actor.
  • The soundtrack and sound design of the film, alongside other post-production aspects.
  • Getting our film into film festival submissions in the UK and hopefully abroad!

 

It’s time to see the talented cast and crew who will be bringing this fantastic project from page to screen!

Louise is the fantastic Producer and Editor for the film, keeping the film together and working behind the scenes to make sure that we have actors to film with and a location to film them at. On top of this, she’ll be the one fitting the pieces together during post-production as our talented editor. It wouldn’t be an exaggeration to say that Louise is the backbone of the production, working hard to produce a quality film for everyone to enjoy.

“Our crew are a hard-working bunch who throw themselves wholly into whatever projects they’re attached to, so it’s safe to say I’m excited and honoured to be working with them. I’m excited to see where this project takes us, and to above all have a fun, safe time with my crew.”

 

The creative brain behind the script and direction of the film, Charley has worked hard to make sure that you, the viewer, have something fun to watch once post-production is all wrapped up. He has been working hard on the script to give everyone something to film, with the crew through the look and feel of the film as well as with the actors in bringing the brilliant characters to life.

“I feel that this is a good opportunity to experiment and express the creativity that we wouldn’t have received with just any script. I believe that this production has a certain uniqueness to it and that the crew and I can make a truly memorable and enjoyable film, both to produce and to watch.”

 

The man behind every schedule and making sure to keep everyone to it, Noël is making sure to get everyone where they need to be at the right time. As well as making sure to keep the shoot on time, he’s also on set to make sure that no one gets hurt and can rest easy about filming in both a productive and safe environment. With a meticulous plan in place, Noël will make sure that not a single second on set is wasted.

“Creatively, ‘More Than a Shadow’ is a short film about differences in generations and how we can still make connections regardless of age. Both generations need to work together to survive and this film could be interpreted as a reminder of this that we can all connect to. Looking forward to it!”

 

Behind the camera is Ashley, our dedicated Director of Photography who has worked tirelessly making sure that every shot is perfectly fleshed out. She’s cleared every lens and camera being used on the film and worked closely with the Director to make sure that every shot says just as much as the actor in it. Creative and talented, her involvement means you will have a film that looks as good as it can.

“The aspects that draw me into working on ‘More Than a Shadow’ would be how open and free the project is in terms of shots and experimentation with camera movement. Working on ‘More Than a Shadow’ is a great opportunity, there is a lot to learn and with my experience on camera I feel like this would be a good role for me to show my skills.”

 

There’s no point in having a nicely shot film if you can’t see half the stuff in it, that’s why Leon is on board to make sure that every shot is lit properly. Working closely with Ashley and Charley, Leon’s work adds creative flair to ensure the tone of every scene is captured expertly through colour and light. The gaffer is also the one in charge of making sure we don’t burn the house down with our electric shenanigans!

“More Than a Shadow is an interesting project for lighting due to its genre mix, creating a dissonance between the story world and characters. I’d like to use this project to work on my skills in the areas of contrast and colour; taking a deeper look at how contrast affects our view on the project's tone and how colour can convey certain feelings about the story world.”

 

Much like how a film without a crew has no legs to stand on, a camera with no tripod has no legs to stand on. Literally. That’s why Hollis, our Key Grip, is in charge of making sure that every piece of lighting and camera equipment is handled properly and ensuring that everything gets to the location safely. He knows how to operate every piece of camera equipment, making him an invaluable part of the team.

“I find the concept of the film interesting since it gives me more room to work with different mounts for the camera, as I believe the story shows potential for a lot of different camera dynamics. I believe I have a good understanding and knowledge of Grip and being able to think outside the box in terms of how to make a certain shot work if there are any problems.”

 

Amelia is a strong-willed, outrageously funny home renovator, and there is no one better suited for the role than Atlanta Hayward. After a successful international tour of ‘Tobacco Road’ with Incognito Theatre, and seeing her showreel, we would’ve been crazy to turn down such a talented actress to play our leading lady.

We got a whopping number of applicants to play the role of Amelia, coming in at over 150 actresses, but Atlanta was the clear choice to play Amelia. During a test shoot, there were moments where the crew couldn’t tell when we were speaking to Atlanta and when we were speaking to Amelia! As shown in our teaser trailer, there’s no doubting her skills.

 

I’ll be honest, we're not sure how we managed to persuade Alistair Petrie to get involved, but he’s very kindly accepted the role of Baron Linwood Bythesea the Poltergeist! Alistair has starred in shows such as ‘Sex Education’ as Michael Groff and ‘Utopia’ as Geoff Lawson, so we are absolutely thrilled to have him on board. When it comes to subtly intimidating presences, Alistair fits the bill perfectly, so casting him as the Baron just made sense. We can’t wait to see him… or hear him rather, bring the role of Baron to life… uh, death? You know what we mean.

 

We're filming at the amazing Pekes Manor in Hailsham! Not only does it fit the character of Baron perfectly as his stately home, but we also have the entire location to work with. It has beautiful wooden panelling as well as a chilling, yet comforting atmosphere, which was just the feeling that we wanted to portray when considering where the Baron would live. Below are some photos of the house as well as pictures we took while scouting out the location!

Here are some moodboards that our wonderful Director of Photography Ashley made while we were pitching our production to our university lecturers:

On top of this, we've had a number of production meetings to work out the shot-list as well as having done a number of test shoots for the purpose of testing special effects, lenses, types of shots and taking photos of our lead actress Atlanta for promotional material. We have put so much work into this production already and we don't plan on slowing down even after we've finished the fundraiser and wrapped on the shoot!

As you can see, we've found a brilliant balance of filming in a fun, yet still very professional environment!

 

This isn’t a one-way process! We want to make sure that you receive something for those feeling generous, with the following perks:

  • £5 - Get your name in the credits of the film - you’ll be seeing your name on the big screen!
  • £20 - Get a digital edition of the film! These won’t be readily available early on, since we are trying to get More Than A Shadow into festivals, so this is a great way to watch the film before the official release.
  • £40 – Get a signed copy of the script with all the cast and crew members’ signatures. For an extra £5 you can get a specific script with annotations from either a specific crew member or actor. It’s an interesting look into the minds of those behind the camera.
  • £60 – Get a crew shirt for More Than A Shadow! Paying as much as you are, you’re practically a part of the team yourself – so dress the part!
  • £85 – Choose between getting an official More Than A Shadow t-shirt, OR an A3 print of the official poster! A nice memento for a film we hope you enjoy.
  • £150 – Get an executive producer credit at the end of the film, as well as either a poster or a t-shirt. You’re the one making this happen, now!
  • £200 – You get an executive producer credit, as well as getting both an official t-shirt and a poster.
  • £500 – You’ll be credited as a co-producer, at the top of the list of executive producers, and alongside our hardworking producer, Louise. You’re coming for her job but without all the strife!

 

While there are always risks with a production, we have been very thorough when it comes to the challenges this production face. Our location is locked, so there’s no risk of losing it and most of our crew are part of the same household, so Covid-19 is less of a risk. On top of that, our Producer and Assistant Director are vigilant with getting the cast and crew tested.

If any issues come up, they will most likely arise from either technical issues that are unforeseeable or issues with post-production involving soundtracks, which is where your generosity will really pay off!

Even if you are unable to assist us financially today, you can still help us out massively by sharing this fundraising page on your social media. By following us on our Instagram page, you can stay in the loop with what we’re doing.

Thank you so, so much for taking a look at our fundraiser page, we can’t wait to show you what we have in store!

story:
DIRECTOR BIO: Taylor Carmona is the Writer, Director, Editor, and Executive Producer for the LAS VIRGENES short film. Carmona was born in Corpus Christi and raised in Bishop, Texas. In 2016, Carmona received her Bachelor's Degree in Art from Texas A&M University-Corpus Christi. After graduating, Carmona began work as a freelance videographer and started her career as an independent writer and filmmaker. Carmona is the founder of the film collective, Pomegranate Vision and has, now, independently produced, written, directed, and edited three short films. As a Texicanx film artist, she aims to capture the history and influences of her heritage by way of visual storytelling and communication in a digital era. She has a passion and dedication to creatively honoring her Latino and Indigenous culture in a way that is authentic to her communities; it is her goal to find and promote new forms of decolonized representation in media and film.

 

EXECUTIVE PRODUCER BIO: Jennifer Bracy is the Executive Producer, Production Manager, and Post-Production Admin for the LAS VIRGENES short film. Bracy has her bachelor's degree in Communication-Media Studies and a minor in Public Relations from Texas A&M University - Corpus Christi, which is also her hometown and where she began her career in film. Bracy continues to work with filmmakers in the South Texas area as a producer and collaborator with Pomegranate Vision. Her current focus is on the austin film community working as a Producer for the Austin Film Society grant supported film CATHARSIS: A Journey Through Anger. As a Texas native, she finds it extremely important to continue the film efforts of the state through festival support and local Austin film initiatives. She greatly enjoys working to promote diversity and inclusion through the cinematic arts. At her core, she is a creative who looks to empower other creatives.

 

Director of Photography Bio: Sarah Jones is the Director of Photography and Cinematographer for the LAS VIRGENES Short Film. In 2015, Sarah graduated from Columbia College Chicago with a BA in Cinema Art + Science, where she focused her studies in digital and film cinematography. Frustrated with the challenges that filmmakers face while trying to break into the industry, Sarah spent the summer of 2016 in Yellowstone National Park to rediscover herself, and along the way fell in love with the state of Montana. She then served as an AmeriCorps VISTA member at MAPS Media Institute in Hamilton, MT, a nationally award winning creative development program for high school students interested in learning about filmmaking, graphic design, music production, computer technology, and entrepreneurship. In the fall of 2018, Sarah moved to Austin to continue her growth as a cinematographer and a female filmmaker.  She currently works with Austin Film Society as a part of their youth education Film Club program, is a co-founder of The Femme House ATX, and freelances.

 

  • Synopsis: LAS VIRGENES details the sisterhood of Luna and her best friends, Lupe, Andi and Esmi, and the pact they made to avoid sexual temptation. The story’s protagonists are four chaste, Latina friends whose strict religious upbringing motivates all of their actions. When Luna falls prey to a young man’s seduction, her friends warn her to be wary of his presence and are, ultimately, validated in their assumption when they discover he has been hiding a part of his life from Luna.

 

  • Focus: Post-production costs are the current primary focus as we edit the film; if you contribute, we would use these fund for payments for sound design, color grading, post-production consulting, and editing.

 

The LAS VIRGENES production is needing funds for:

Editing

Includes fees for: operational costs, cutting of a 15-minute and 20-minute version of the short film, cutting the teaser trailer, cutting reel clips for each lead/minor roles, cutting all behind the scenes video content.

Sound Mixing

Includes fees for sound design for 20-minute short film, 45-second teaser trailer, and sound recording for a director bio video; to be divided and paid to our two key sound designers, the consulting composer and musician.

Color Grading 

Includes fees for: operational costs, color grading of a 20-minute version of the short film and the teaser trailer.

Post-Production Consultant Admin

Includes fee for Grant Writing, Human Resources, and overall Production Management.

Distribution

Includes fee costs for Film Festival Submissions; to be spent in three phases: Fall/Winter 2021, Spring 2022, Summer 2022.

We are grateful for every contribution and will work to ensure that any and all funds from this campaign will directly contribute to the film whether the entire goal is met or not. 

 

  • The LAS VIRGENES Production was self and independently funded; along with in-kind sponsorship and donors for the remaining preproduction and production needs. The production received monetary contributions, Carmona’s personal financial investment, and independent crowdfunding to cover production, equipment, crew, and craft services fees. Currently, we are in Post-Production editing the film down to 15 minutes; with full sound design to be added in a month. Once the score is finalized, we intend to send it out for a final color grading process.

 

  • For LAS VIRGENES, we were tested with the pandemic, some experiencing unemployment, and our whole team experiencing hardships, there were many times when we could have given up. However, with our continued perseverance and resilience, we found ways to make it work. Our grit, determination, and our overall love for the craft of filmmaking kept us going; which is why we know we can overcome any financial hurdle and finish this film.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to contribute:

  • Share our campaign!
  • Follow us on Instagram and Facebook!

Includes fees for: operational costs, cutting of a 15-minute and 20-minute version of the short film, cutting the teaser trailer, cutting reel clips for each lead/minor roles, cutting all behind the scenes video content.
Sound Mixing
Includes fees for sound design for 20-minute short film, 45-second teaser trailer, and sound recording for a director bio video; to be divided and paid to our two key sound designers, the consulting composer and musician.
Color Grading 
Includes fees for: operational costs, color grading of a 20-minute version of the short film and the teaser trailer.
Post-Production Consultant Admin
Includes fee for Grant Writing, Human Resources, and overall Production Management.
Distribution
Includes fee costs for Film Festival Submissions; to be spent in three phases: Fall/Winter 2021, Spring 2022, Summer 2022.
We are grateful for every contribution and will work to ensure that any and all funds from this campaign will directly contribute to the film whether the entire goal is met or not. 

 
The LAS VIRGENES Production was self and independently funded; along with in-kind sponsorship and donors for the remaining preproduction and production needs. The production received monetary contributions, Carmona’s personal financial investment, and independent crowdfunding to cover production, equipment, crew, and craft services fees. Currently, we are in Post-Production editing the film down to 15 minutes; with full sound design to be added in a month. Once the score is finalized, we intend to send it out for a final color grading process.
 
For LAS VIRGENES, we were tested with the pandemic, some experiencing unemployment, and our whole team experiencing hardships, there were many times when we could have given up. However, with our continued perseverance and resilience, we found ways to make it work. Our grit, determination, and our overall love for the craft of filmmaking kept us going; which is why we know we can overcome any financial hurdle and finish this film.

Other Ways You Can Help
If you are unable to contribute:

Share our campaign!
Follow us on Instagram and Facebook!

story:
A couple's quiet romantic drive through backcountry roads turns into a horrific encounter with an unknown evil. What happens when everything you thought you knew about someone you love comes into question? What happens when evil knows you better than you know yourself?

Productive Lens Studio is proud to present the IndieGoGo crowdfunding campaign for our new short psychological horror-thriller "Effigy."

Productive Lens Studio aims to create thought and emotion-driven stories with top-notch production quality. 

Matthew Frey Allen - Director/Writer

Matthew Frey Allen is native to southern Illinois; however, he grew up in several states across America. After studying film and working on various student projects, he focused primarily on screenwriting and short film work. One of his short films, "Action Movie 3: The Sequel", premiered at the LA Film Prize in Shreveport, Louisiana, and placed in their top 20 selection. He both wrote and starred in AM3. From there, he directed, wrote, and produced several short films and commercial projects. In recent years he has turned his attention primarily to writing feature spec scripts. He wrote one such script with his writing partner and is currently a semifinalist in the 2021 Scriptapalooza international screenplay competition.

Brandon Fountain - Director Of Photography

While being born and raised in Shreveport, La, Brandon Fountain has become a media audio engineer, musician, video producer, editor, filmmaker, podcast creator, and host. 

By May 2017, he became the Owner of Productive Lens Studio, a video and film production business based in Shreveport, LA serving small businesses and collaborating with outside filmmakers to bring better quality to the northwest Louisiana area. So far he has Brandon Fountain has worked on three feature-length sets and two short films. Effigy will be the first In-House Film he will produce alongside Matthew Allen.

Haley Summerlin - Kali

Haley is an aspiring artist from Natchitoches, Louisiana. She is currently a student at Northwestern State University studying studio art/graphic design and film studies. She has grown up in the professional haunt industry and loves to create prosthetics for local film productions!

Coty Lewis - Mike

Coty is well versed and studied in various forms of media. Besides his formal training in the entertainment industry, he has years of involvement in creating visceral horror experiences for large audiences. Specifically, he has been and is currently the House Manager at the popular Shreveport area attraction, "Necromanor," and works as a virtual reality operator at GGVR in Shreveport. His acting and special effects experience will be a great asset to his role as Mike and back-end post-production.

Each member of our team is making a significant monetary contribution towards the production of Effigy. However, to ensure the production and post-production run smoothly, we're strongly relying on fundraising for the remainder of our budget. Our goal is to raise a total of $1500.

Your donations will go straight towards the production of Effigy:

Equipment: Any equipment we're unable to access for free will be rented. Kit includes but is not limited to Accsoon CineEye 2S Pro Wireless Video Transmitter & Receiver and Godox VL300. 

Actor's Pay and Accommodations: We make sure our actors are always paid and accommodated. We need to make sure they have a comfortable place to sleep after traveling and each production day.

Art Department: Props, set dressing, and wardrobes will be thrifted or discounted to keep expenses to a minimum, and we hope to hire a hair and make-up artist for each day of our production.

Post-Production: We'd love to hire a colorist, so our final product looks the way we've imagined.

Food: Meals and water are a huge part of our budget. Your donations will allow us to comfortably create the film we're passionate about and not stress about spending most of the budget on food expenses.

We plan to complete our shooting by late September and screen our film in late October. Along the way, we'll be posting promotional content on our social media to give you inside looks at the production process!

We're grateful for any support we receive. Whether it's donations, sharing the link to our IndieGoGo Campaign, following us on social media. Regardless, we are forever grateful to every individual who supports us along the way.

Follow us on Instagram @effigy_movie to keep up with our production!
