story:
About the Film

Recovering from the loss of her mother, Jade must navigate her first love on her own. Jade, a shy, out-lesbian high-schooler, falls into rollerskating as she struggles to garner the attention of Parkwood High’s most eligible queer, Glo.

Why This Film Matters

Most queer Black movies center traumatic outings, shunning from families, and relationships in the shadows where the villain or obstacle to overcome is their sexuality. Queer Black kids lack a playbook for healthy relationships living outside of shame. GLO provides a look into what they can look like, focusing on the lighter, aspects of falling in love and pursuing a crush for the first time. Joy is a radical change-maker, and my most powerful tool in uplifting the communities I inhabit. I create art that makes us smile, reminds us of our awkward moments, and brings us closer to finding our passions. GLO focuses on an average queer Black girl, seeking joy amidst her grief featuring an unequivocally supportive parent responsive to change and correction, and storytelling focusing more on the nuance of Jade’s journey with Glo than hyper-focusing on their identity labels.

Last and certainly not least, I seek to reclaim the name of rollerblading and rollerskating for queer folks as a radical act, taking up space in a historically toxic straight white male-dominated field in which they’re historically shunned. 

How To Help

We are currently fundraising for production. Our total project budget is $25K, we are hoping to raise $15K via crowdfunding. The $15K will cover costs for the majority of meals, equipment rentals, and crew pay. For the remaining $10K, we are applying for grants to cover post-production needs and outstanding production costs. We are also accepting in-kind donations (i.e. space, equipment)  or meal donations as well. 

 

Timeline/Process

We are aiming to do a 1- day shoot in late October to film a teaser, and a 3-day shoot in early spring. Once completed, we plan to submit to film festivals and do local screenings at skating rinks in the city. 

 

Audiences

This project was created to serve and highlight young Black and queer audiences. While queer Black young folks are who the storytelling is centered around, the story will impact queer folks across all communities. Additionally, the project highlights the history of roller skating as a community-building tool for the Black community, which we hope entices members of the Black community who may not seek out these stories on their own to enjoy our queer love story.  With a story featuring queer skate and Black skate culture we plan to pull on these communities for support and viewership.  

 

 

Adhana Reid (Writer/Actor/Co-Director) is an actor, writer, singer, and dancer based in Chicago. Living out her praxis of an ‘occupation with joy,’ she fills her life through DJing curated spaces to amplify Black joy, and rollerskating as meditation. This burgeoning screenwriter focuses her storytelling efforts around art that uplifts and empowers Black lesbian and queer joy. Originally hailing from Maryland, she received both her bachelor’s in Theatre and her Masters in Marketing from Northwestern University. After finding a new home in the flourishing artistic community Chicago had to offer, she went on to perform in various local theatres. Chicago credits include: MICHAEL JACKSON & THE DEVIL’S BOOK (Jackalope Theatre); SCHOOL GIRLS: OR THE AFRICAN MEAN GIRLS PLAY(Goodman Theatre); The MLK Project (Writers Theatre); SHEEPDOG (Shattered Globe); A CHRISTMAS CAROL, THE COLOR PURPLE (Drury Lane Theatre); LITTLE SHOP OF HORRORS (Mercury Theatre); FANTASTIC MR. FOX (Emerald City Theatre); ECLIPSED (Pegasus Theatre); BIG RIVER (Theatre at the Center); & SPRING AWAKENING (Marriott Theatre). You can follow her journey on social media @uhh_dah_nuh or adhanareid.com

 

Angellic Ross (Producing Consultant)

 Raised in Milwaukee, Angellic Ross (she/her) attended Northwestern University where she studied Performance Studies and Film & Media Studies. Her first short film was revoLUZion which won first place at the My Hero Festival. Following that, she produced the short film Down the Rabbit Hole which was nominated for Best Picture at the Single Take Film Festival.

Her most recent project is a multimedia documentary piece, A Journey Through Time, for her sorority's 100 year anniversary. She is an Advisory Board Member of Sisters in Cinema and a part of the inaugural class of Full Spectrum Features and the Chicago Film Office's Chicago Independent Producers Lab. In addition to her film work, Angellic is an Associate Director of Media Strategy at an advertising agency. Check out her work here.

story:
Live Well Done

  • Featured on DEADLINE
  • Featured on Metal Life
  • Featured on TaleFlick
  • Live Well Done website
  • Well Done Comedian website

 

HAVE YOU HEARD OF THE

WELL DONE COMEDIAN?

Bobby Henline is an American war veteran, a Purple Heart recipient, a burn survivor, and Wounded Warrior. While serving as a paratrooper on his 4th tour in Iraq, Bobby suffered burns on over 40% of his body. While in recovery at the hospital, Bobby turned to humor as therapy. He was cracking jokes from left to right and had every doctor and nurse rolling on the floor laughing. It wasn't until one of the therapists pushed Bobby to give stand-up comedy a chance, that he began his career. 

We are filming Bobby as he goes on a cross-country road trip of the U.S., making people laugh, smile, and bringing joy while reminding us how beautiful life is. From comedy clubs to small ventures, our journey is one of comic redemption, post-trauma, and most importantly, hope.

The end of our road trip will also culminate our cinematic journey, which will serve as the start of Bobby's own TV special. We're going to discover Bobby's inspiring tale through the different perspectives found through America and the ways in which people use humor to connect.

What We Need & What You Get

Simply put, we need funding. Whether you can donate $1.00 or $100.000 – every little bit counts. 

Bobby’s story needs to be heard! For anyone living with trauma, or simply needing a laugh, Bobby’s comedy is for you. Go on our live journey to experience emotional reactions of anger, sadness, survivor’s guilt, numbness, and anxiety through interactions with family, friends, and strangers or simply going to the grocery store. 

You will see firsthand how society reacts and then acts when encountering someone who “looks” different. Walk the road of hyperarousal, triggers, flashbacks, behavioral changes, and social reactions as Bobby continues his journey of Living Well Done. Finally, you will see and feel the impact he is making with combat veterans, first responders, and Gold Star Family members through the non-profit Forging Forward, of which he is a co-founder.

We're offering limited edition Live Well Done merchandise. Check our perks section for more information!

Budget

Our Flexible Goal is $50,000, which is the bare minimum to start filming. Our Total Budget is $150,000, which will get us from pre-production all the way to a finished film.

Budget: $150,000

Pre-production: $20,000

location, organizational, insurance, permits

Production: $90,000

crew, equipment, transportation, and accommodation (fuel, food, flights, shelter)

Post-production: $40,000

editing, sound, music, distribution, festival submission

What happens if we exceed our flexible goal?

The Flexible Goal is the minimal budget to start the initial filming. To complete the filming and to move the final film to professional venues, it is estimated that a Total Budget of $150,000 is required. The Total Budget includes pre-production expenses, professional film and post-production crew, transportation and accommodations for all parties, music, distribution, and film festival submissions.

What happens if the Flexible Goal and Total Budget are not reached?

If the Flexible Goal and Total Budget are not reached through Indiegogo, the movie will still be made – but it may take a little longer! Our team will use additional crowdfunding platforms, grants, shop it to film producers, investors, and backers, and other opportunities that come our way.

Estimated Timeline

Pre-Production: November 2021 - March 2022

Filming: April 2022 - June 2022

Post-Production: July 2022 - September 2022

The Impact

Bobby's story is an inspiring one. It demonstrates the power of laughter to overcome life's greatest challenges. In a day and age of isolation and widespread mental health difficulties, we know that if Bobby's story gets out there, it will inspire people to find ways to smile and appreciate all the beauty that life has to offer, albeit our obstacles and disabilities.

Award-winning director Nony Geffen will direct “Live Well Done.” Geffen has two feature films under his belt, four Israeli Oscar nominations (three for a feature, one for a short), has shadow-directed Oscar-winning director Peter Farrelly, and is, above all, an artist who follows stories that he believes in! 

The Team

Risks & Challenges

Filmmaking is filled with risks and challenges. Timelines change, budgetary restrictions force you to come up with creative solutions. We're asking for money to kick off this documentary. It will cover equipment and travel costs for filming Bobby's cross-country road trip, including comedy shows, motivational speaking gigs, and conversations between Bobby and those he meets along the way. When this stage is finished, we will be able to shop our cut around to get additional funding for the post-production process.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute, that doesn't mean you can't help:

Please share the word of Bobby's inspiring story and support our film by following Bobby on Instagram @bobby_henline, on Facebook as Bobby Henline, or TikTok @bobbyhenline. You can also use the Indiegogo share tools!

Press Contact: 

Jasmin Espada
Espada PR LLC
(818) 521-3807
jasmin@espadapr.com

Representation:

Sean Dubravac
Entertainment Lab
(323) 746-5003
sean@entlab.la

Special Thanks to Editor Nitay Dagan, Narrator Zach Cohen and Photographer Peter van Agtmael.

story:
Conan is an only child, who is treated like royalty by his parents, especially his Papa and nothing changes on the day of his birthday. He is promised the biggest present of them all, but he isn't allowed to open it until his party. He decides to try and find his present, under his alias 'Special Agent Conan', but ends up discovering something much more eye-opening that dramatically changes his life forever.

THE NAME

It was difficult to name this film as we wanted to create a name that wouldn't give away the story, but would entice people to it. We came up with Kaleidoscope after watching the film and seeing Conan picking up one, that's when we thought about how the a Kaleidoscope is made up of a lot of colours, and so is our story.

THE IMPORTANCE OF OUR FILM

This short film has themes of family, trust, love and dishonour, all of which are so important to society today. It is also a film that centres around domestic abuse and the lies that families face behind closed doors, away from society. For us, domestic abuse is an important subject to be talking about and, we know many films centre around the subject, but we believe that telling the story from the child's perspective, almost like an adventure film, creates more tension as we move to create a resolution.

We would be extremely grateful if you are able to help us push this message out by donating to our film.

SO, WHO ARE THE TEAM?

Marissa Cole is an American Producer who has produced a wide range of productions. From successful short films, to behind the scenes, all the way to music videos, she has been working all over England. Marissa plans to take this knowledge and bring this great film to the states. She is a huge advocate for the welfare of children and a supporter of the Children’s Miracle Network, which is what inspired her to make this film.

Nicole Pott has been directing and/or producing films for around four years, through her production company, Sonder Pictures, of which she runs out of Manchester. Her short film 'Charlie' was picked up in festivals across the world and won 'Best Short Film' at Monkey Bread Tree Film Festival and her second short film 'Rambling On' was selected at Long Beach Indie International Film, Music and Media Festival in LA. In 2016, she completed her debut feature film 'In a Year', which was also selected at the same film festival and nominated for 'Best Dramatic Comedy' too. 'Same Old, Same Old' that she believes is to be the staple piece of her portfolio so far.

The film is written by Stuti Nair. Originally from Mumbai, India she is behind some of their most successful advertisements and film campaigns. Writing since she was five years old, Stuti is currently working on a feature length fantasy drama, and like our film, it’s main focus is around children. She is also writing a TV pilot and several shorts at the moment.

Tania wanted to do something adventurous and ground breaking that she could embrace, feeling passionate about and grow with.  In time honoured fashion, she started out as a assistant in the camera dept, one day she got a call asking if she'd DP a 16mm film starring Brian Blessed.  Since then she's shot Commercials, Documentaries and Award Winning Narrative Short Film Drama, she is a proud to be a member of GBCT & BAFTA Crew.

A HUGE THANK YOU TO OUR ON-SET CREW:

1st AD - Axel Garkman

2nd AD - Morgan Davies

DOP Assistant - Ana Pcelinceva

1st AC - Daniel Sarpong

2nd AC - Alex Dando

Hair & Makeup - Fiona Kerrigan

Costume - Lucy Scrimgeour

Script Supervisor - Stefanie Matei

Runner - Elle Swainsbury

Gaffer/ Spark - Qutaibah Alkhateeb

Sound Recordist - Thurston Thomson

What We Need & What You Get

We are looking for £3000 to be able to pay for our post-production of the film, with excellent sound design, music composition and colour grading to go with our cut of the film. No film is complete without any of these and we don't want to release this film to the world without completing the film first.

Our Post-Production Team:

Bringing the story to life through the edit, Rob Maxwell is working hard with director, Nicole Pott, to get this film onto the big screen. Rob and Nicole have worked together on numerous occasions and in early 2018, became business partners together at Sonder Pictures Ltd. Rob has edited numerous projects, included his own with his production company, Sic Infit, and recently a horror feature film.

Richard Collins is a fantastic composer, who has worked on various projects over his career. He has worked with Nicole on two projects 'Rambling On', of which he was nominated for Best Score at The Monkey Bread Tree Film Festival and the crowdfunder for 'Bonnie'. He is working to build a fantastic score for this short film that will be really emotive!

Hear all his work here: https://soundcloud.com/rcollins-121923343

Sherice Griffiths is a British film maker who grew up in Ashford Middlesex. Sherice attended Westminster University where she graduated with a BA in Film and TV production. Since then Sherice has been working freelance in the film and television industry as a Film Director and 1st Assistant Director. Sherice has been fortunate enough to work alongside Daniel Radcliff, Adam Godfrey and Neil Mcdermott in various productions.
 
 
James Chatwin is an independent UK filmmaker, with freelance work across a range of documentary and drama and factual entertainment. Based in the South West of England, he is a graduate from Film at Falmouth University (BA) and Film and Television (MA) at Falmouth.
 
https://jameschatwin.com/
 

On top of this, we will be putting some money towards our film festival campaign as we hit the big festivals i.e. Atlanta, Cannes, Athens, San Luis.

If we don't reach our goal, we will use the money towards the costs, whilst we continue to raise a further finishing fund. 

Should you wish to contribute to our film, we will ship ALL perks within 45 days of the specified date on the perks. If you do not receive notification that your gift has been sent, you may ask for your money back.

THE IMPORTANCE OF OUR FILM

This short film has themes of family, trust, love and dishonour, all of which are so important to society today. It is also a film that centres around domestic abuse and the lies that families face behind closed doors, away from society. For us, domestic abuse is an important subject to be talking about and, we know many films centre around the subject, but we believe that telling the story from the child's perspective, almost like an adventure film, creates more tension as we move to create a resolution.

We would be extremely grateful if you are able to help us push this message out by donating to our film.

DOMESTIC ABUSE CHARITIES

Domestic abuse is an important thing to talk about, especially for children who are involved mentally or physically, and we want to support charities that work hard to help children in those situations.

We are donating 10% of all the funds that we make from this campaign to NSPCC because we believe children deserve a better chance at happiness in their life.
story_txt:
Conan is an only child, who is treated like royalty by his parents, especially his Papa and nothing changes on the day of his birthday. He is promised the biggest present of them all, but he isn't allowed to open it until his party. He decides to try and find his present, under his alias 'Special Agent Conan', but ends up discovering something much more eye-opening that dramatically changes his life forever.

THE NAME
It was difficult to name this film as we wanted to create a name that wouldn't give away the story, but would entice people to it. We came up with Kaleidoscope after watching the film and seeing Conan picking up one, that's when we thought about how the a Kaleidoscope is made up of a lot of colours, and so is our story.

THE IMPORTANCE OF OUR FILM
This short film has themes of family, trust, love and dishonour, all of which are so important to society today. It is also a film that centres around domestic abuse and the lies that families face behind closed doors, away from society. For us, domestic abuse is an important subject to be talking about and, we know many films centre around the subject, but we believe that telling the story from the child's perspective, almost like an adventure film, creates more tension as we move to create a resolution.
We would be extremely grateful if you are able to help us push this message out by donating to our film.

SO, WHO ARE THE TEAM?


Marissa Cole is an American Producer who has produced a wide range of productions. From successful short films, to behind the scenes, all the way to music videos, she has been working all over England. Marissa plans to take this knowledge and bring this great film to the states. She is a huge advocate for the welfare of children and a supporter of the Children’s Miracle Network, which is what inspired her to make this film.



Nicole Pott has been directing and/or producing films for around four years, through her production company, Sonder Pictures, of which she runs out of Manchester. Her short film 'Charlie' was picked up in festivals across the world and won 'Best Short Film' at Monkey Bread Tree Film Festival and her second short film 'Rambling On' was selected at Long Beach Indie International Film, Music and Media Festival in LA. In 2016, she completed her debut feature film 'In a Year', which was also selected at the same film festival and nominated for 'Best Dramatic Comedy' too. 'Same Old, Same Old' that she believes is to be the staple piece of her portfolio so far.


The film is written by Stuti Nair. Originally from Mumbai, India she is behind some of their most successful advertisements and film campaigns. Writing since she was five years old, Stuti is currently working on a feature length fantasy drama, and like our film, it’s main focus is around children. She is also writing a TV pilot and several shorts at the moment.



Tania wanted to do something adventurous and ground breaking that she could embrace, feeling passionate about and grow with.  In time honoured fashion, she started out as a assistant in the camera dept, one day she got a call asking if she'd DP a 16mm film starring Brian Blessed.  Since then she's shot Commercials, Documentaries and Award Winning Narrative Short Film Drama, she is a proud to be a member of GBCT & BAFTA Crew.

story:
**Please follow us on our Facebook page (link below) for updates on the campaign as well as New Interview Announcements!***

Directed by Robert Hiltzik and Michael A. Simpson, since Debuted in Theaters on November 18th 1983 has since become one of the most loved horrors of the 1980s. With Felissa Rose and Pamela Springsteen's  amazing portrayal of Angela Baker, the two slashers and Sleepaway Camp themselves have become iconic images of the horror genre.

PLEASE NOTE: This is an 'all or nothing' campaign - it just wont be possible without the minimum funding total required. 

DVD and Blu-ray will be Multi-Region NTSC

https://www.facebook.com/Angela-The-Sleepaway-C...

From Michael Perez Entertainment and MPSO Ent, maker of MORE BRAINS! A Return To The Living Dead, Crystal Lake Memories: The Complete History of Friday the 13th,  You're so cool, Brewster! The Story of Fright Night and RoboDoc: The Creation of RoboCop  comes this brand-new documentary ANGELA ~ The Definitive Sleepaway Camp Documentary. A fully independent retrospective into the making of Robert Hiltzik's Classic Story and its cultural impact over the last 36 years. Supported by dozens of the original cast and crew including: Felissa Rose (Executive Producer), Katherine Kamhi, Karen Fields, Jonathan Tiersten, Thomas Van Dell, Paul DeAngelo, Michael A. Simpson, Robert Hiltzik... And so many more! The crew have already received support from over 35 of the cast and crew, including acquiring over 4 hours of never-before-seen set footage from the Directors and Crew, as well as loads of archival and behind-the-scenes photos and there is no doubt that by the time of production many more key players will be attached to share their amazing stories about one of the most iconic movies ever-made. 

https://www.facebook.com/Angela-The-Sleepaway-C...

The documentary is made as a labour of love by a team of HAPPY CAMPERS and this is YOUR unique opportunity to get on board and not only be part of this amazing project BUT make it a reality.

 

ATTENTION CAMPERS!!  

This is a limited edition region free Blu Ray release and is limited to 5000 copies.  This is going to be the only way to get a copy of this documentary.  Sure you will see it on Television and on selective streaming services, but to hold a physical copy of this you must pre-order here from this campaign. 

Please visit and like our Facebook page and help spread the word. 

https://www.facebook.com/Angela-The-Sleepaway-C...

  

 

 

AND MANY MANY MORE!!!! Please check the Facebook page for a complete and updated list of interviewees.

story:
Astromon! is an anime-inspired dark-comedy adventure- when a Yakuza clan’s powerful Asteroid Crystal is stolen, and the highest ranking Lieutenants are devoured by Supernatural monsters, the boss sends her reclusive son, his Rental Sister, and unstable friends to find it.

 

 

In the near future, an asteroid strikes earth ending civilization as we know it. While survivors attempt to rebuild humans are met with a new life-form called-

 

 

 

Natural Astromon- Animals with powers that are mostly friendly.

 

 

 

 

Supernatural Astromon- Grotesque monsters that are a existential threat.

 

 

 

 

 

Gangsang is one of the last cities on earth and was built 100 years after The Great Asteroid struck. It's a chaotic run-down city that is separated by Yakuza clans. 

 

 

 

 

 

Anti-Supernatural Unit

  • The ASU are Yakuza units responsible for protecting their tribes from the Supernatural Astromon.  Clans will often declare villages their own territory and as a result force payment for "protection." 

 

 

 

 

 

DUSTY- A drug addicted shut-in who dreams of taking over the family Yakuza.

 

 

 

IZZIE- Dusty’s Waifu, a Death Goddess who is Isekei’d into the life of a working-class girl on earth learning to deal with mortality, and other issues, while trying to figure out how to return to her goddess form.

 

 

 

 

MONICA-  Dusty's Rental-Sister helping him out of his depression, but being a "sister" takes a toll on her own mental health.  She takes pills called "Smiley's" to help her through the day.

 

 

 

 

ENA- The boss of a powerful Yakuza Clan. Somebody stole a existential weapon from her, and she is ready to wage war to get it back. 

 

 

 

 

 

CHARLIE- The life-long bestfriend of Dusty who only wants to be accepted in the Yakuza.  His hunger for acceptance often lands him in trouble.

 

 

 

 

YO- Physically strong but mentally slow. Yo works as a personal body-guard for a powerful Yakuza boss, and lives as Dusty, Monica, and Charlie’s roommate.

 

 

 

HIMA- A mysterious Yakuza girl thought to be a prodigy. 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

In order to create consistently smooth animation, beautiful backgrounds, and to make an overall grand 10-12 minute Pilot Episode we'll need to raise about

 

$40k

 

 

  • Any extra will go toward upgrading quality and/or length and/or more episodes! 

 

 Scroll up and select - BACK IT - if you want to donate any amount. 

  • 5$ - Thank You 
  • 10$- Your Name in the Credits
  • 20$- Art Book (Digital)
  • 40$-  Astromon! Sticker
  • 50$- Original Scripts (Digital) 
  • 75$- Astromon! Music OST (Digital)
  • 100$- Storyboards (Digital) 
  • 120$- Black T-shirt w/ Astromon! Logo
  • 1,000$- Get drawn in the background 
  • 1,500$- Get drawn in the background- as a Yakuza
  • 2,000$ Get drawn in the background- as a corpse  
  • 3,000$- Credit you as Executive Producer 

 

 

Share this campaign on social media, share the video's, and that would mean a lot! 

Newgrounds - Twitter - Youtube - Tiktok - Facebook


More information regarding the show go to http://www.astromon.net.

story:
Can a 23-year-old first-generation Mexican-American woman lift her city out of poverty?

"I want to show people what happens when you believe in something," says Giselle Martinez.

One in three. That’s the ratio of people living below the poverty line in Newburgh, New York. And most of them come from Black and Brown communities. Newburgh is one of the most impoverished cities nestled in the expansive Hudson Valley. Its neighboring river towns have steadily climbed their way out of poverty. But Newburgh is far behind.

Giselle Martinez believes in her city and has bold plans for its future. That's why she's running for city council. At just 23-years-old, Giselle would be the youngest council member in Newburgh history. But not everyone in Newburgh believes in Giselle. Her age and ethnicity have caused an outbreak of racism and xenophobia.

 

As Giselle has said, “So goes Newburgh, so goes America”

The United States is at a crossroads and a possible political breaking point. From federal immigration camps at the US-Mexico border to social protests due to the killing of Black people across the country, the nation faces a public reckoning, upheaval, and urgent crisis. 

Giselle has personally encountered the effects of immigration-xenophobia and police violence. In fact, that’s one of the many reasons she decided to run for office. Many, if not most, of these national problems, will be hurdles Giselle faces in Here to Stay. And because of this, the film will bring these national crises into direct conversation.

 

Here's a statement from Director and Producer Jared Peraglia:

I was born and raised in the Hudson Valley. Its diverse culture, people, and stories continue to have an unwavering impact on my life. And from this, I’ve always been under the belief that some of the best stories to tell can be found in our own backyards. In fact, my documentary Washington Street explored the attempted move of a homeless shelter that faced phobic opposition in the small riverside city of Peekskill. What I uncovered by making Washington Street is that Peekskill was dealing with an issue much larger than itself. And from this, I’ve learned the power of film, specifically documentary, to rally communities, encourage conversation, and ignite progress.

Newburgh, and Giselle, are only one hour up the river from the town where I grew up. Learning about Giselle’s campaign, I was taken by the pure passion she has for her city and was inspired to learn she shares a love for the people of the Hudson Valley and the mutual belief in making it a fairer and more equitable place. As our ideals aligned, the notion to make a documentary seemed obvious. And with that, Here to Stay was born. Not only is Giselle’s story timely in national conversations about race and identity, but in fact, I believe her story is a vital microcosm to understanding the scarred American condition, how to face fear, and deliver hope.

 

Documentary production is expensive and often serves as a deterrent to creatives looking to produce work. By meeting our goal, production costs for Here to Stay will be greatly alleviated. We'll be able to tell Giselle's story at the high-quality level it deserves to be told.

By funding our project, you aren't just fueling the future of young talented filmmakers. You are also helping to bring a story to the big screen that does not typically get told. It's no secret that Latine stories are underrepresented in the world of film and television. By funding Here to Stay to bring Giselle's story to life, you are helping people across the country see themselves on screen, and in Giselle's case, in leadership positions.

story:
This Story

"Nice To Meet You All"  is a short documentary that tells the story of Bri, a woman with Dissociative Identity Disorder, who has survived human trafficking rings across America and the UK.   The film follows her in her everyday life, alongside five of her sixty-five "alters" - the different personalities she has because of D.I.D. 

Why This Story?

We want to show mental health in a different light. Mental health problems are not a walk in the park, but they don't always have to be represented by the 'misery porn' often shown in the media.

Survivors - whether from human trafficking like our documentary, mental illness, sexual assault, domestic violence or any other kind of abuse -  are among the strongest and most beautiful people we know. 

This is why we want to make this film. A film about someone who's been through it, by someone who's been through it also.  And we want to share it with you to open a wonderful, sincere conversation.

With your help - we can do it

    How The Money Will Help

    We're hoping to raise £6,250 from this campaign, which will go towards the production (the shoot) of this film, including the cast, crew, camera & lighting equipment, costumes, props, transport and catering. We will also need some money for post-production, including editing, grading, sound design and music. And finally, we'll be putting the film on the film festival circuit for as many people as possible to see!

     

     

    5% of funding from this campaign will go to the Amies Freedom Choir, an organisation working with survivors of human trafficking, a project set up by Pan Intercultural Arts, that uses the arts for social change by working with those on the margins of society.

    Check out the perks we've got for you by clicking on them!

     

    The Impact

    This project will contribute to the mental health narrative. It will put survivors in a different light, as creators of their own script.

    The film will be similar in tone to previous work - like Guen's novel "The Jiggle"  - which is a very open hearted story about psychosis. The book was long listed at the Bridport Prize in 2018. It has its sad moments,  but it's also about the everyday, the achievements, and the absolutely surreal humour that certain situations can bring. This is the mood we will to bring to "Nice To Meet You All".

    "Guen Murroni creates a powerful short film on DID, encapsulating, through the solitary presence of the main protagonist, the sense of alienation and confusion and often terror, the person suffering from this complex disorder experience as they go about their daily lives. As the viewer tries to connect with the different parts of the protagonist's self they witness the efforts made by the sufferer to bring them together in order to build a cohesive narrative of their internal world, making it thus richer and less lonely somehow." Katy Gilardi, Psychodynamic Therapist, Brighton Counselling Collective.

     

    Risks & Challenges

    COVID-19 will be a physical challenge on the shoot. We will ensure both cast and crew are all safe during the filming and post production. 

    This film is unique in its approach and it is transparent. Transparency can be a very new experience for many.  But as someone who has personally overcome mental health problems, I am confident this film will set the boundaries for new storytelling. It will be an opportunity for discussions on these subjects outside of the film world.

    The plan is to share this film with schools, psychologists and survivors to open a much bigger conversation around mental health and trafficking. As well as festivals, we want the film to tour schools and any organisations that would benefit from viewing.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    If you can't contribute to the campaign, we would love you to share it with your network!

    You can share this page directly from the social media links below or email it out to friends and family!  We would appreciate your help in any way you can give it.

     

    Our Team

    Guen Murroni - Writer/Director

    Guen is an award winning writer/director. Her films have been nominated at BAFTA and BIFA-recognised festivals. Fee was nominated for Best British Short at Iris Prize 2019.  Guen’s TV Pilot Hors D’ouevres was longlisted for the New Voices Award (Debbies Awards). Her feature We Love You Searlie was long listed at TIFF Filmmakers Lab 2018.  Her novel The Jiggle was long listed at the Bridport Prize 2018.  She is represented by Independent Talent.

    Verity Wislocki - Producer

    Verity is a producer with 20 years experience in ﬁlm, Verity has worked on films by Tim Burton, Alfonso Cuarón, Terry Gilliam, Anthony Minghella and Yorgos Lanthimos. Verity produced critically-acclaimed award-winning feature documentary Another News Story which has appeared in over 30 ﬁlm festivals worldwide, had a theatrical release and is on iTunes, Amazon, Google Play. Verity was longlisted as Breakthrough Producer at the 2018 BIFAs. She currently has two documentary features in post-production – X Trillion and On Our Doorstep. http://www.wislockifilms.com

    Morgan Tovey Frost - Co Producer

    Morgan Tovey Frost is a film, festival and event producer. Co-producer of 16 Days 16 Films for Modern Films and the TriForce Short Film Festival, her focus has been working to spotlight underrepresented film makers and new talent. Morgan worked with Idris Elba’s Green Door Pictures, in co-production with Lionsgate UK, to produce the new writing competition Write To Green Light. Also working on the development of off-screen projects for both Green Door and The Ink Factory. Morgan’s background in talent management (incl. United Agents and Curtis Brown) and talent booking for organisations such as BAFTA established strong relationships with creatives across the industry as well as grounding her in script and story development. Morgan is currently developing more documentary focused work.

    Hannah Almond Barr - Cast

    Hannah trained at the Oxford School of Drama. Hannah received a Best Acting Nomination at BAFTA recognised UnderWire Festival for her performance in Playground, a short written and directed by Guen Murroni. Recent work include 3 episodes in "The Bisexual" by Desiree Akhavan on Channel 4 and Hulu, an episode on Lake Erie 2 for the Discovery Channel and a series regular in the mini webseries Spoon The Prune.  Hannah is currently on the Writers Lab programme with Soho Theatre.

    Robbie Bryant - Director of Photography

    Robbie is an award-winning cinematographer who began working in the camera department in his teens, assisting on studio films such as Harry Potter, Captain America, Skyfall and Under the Skin. His filmmaking journey has been shaped by his experiences working on projects with directors such as Ridley Scott, Christopher Nolan, Stephen Spielberg and cinematographers John Mathieson, Roger Deakins and Philipe Rouselot. He studied under the tutelage of several cinematographers on commercials and music videos before a mentorship spanning several years with Haris Zambarloukos on the feature films Locke, Jack Ryan and Cinderella – also working as a camera operator on the latter.
story_txt:
This Story
"Nice To Meet You All"  is a short documentary that tells the story of Bri, a woman with Dissociative Identity Disorder, who has survived human trafficking rings across America and the UK.   The film follows her in her everyday life, alongside five of her sixty-five "alters" - the different personalities she has because of D.I.D. 
Why This Story?
We want to show mental health in a different light. Mental health problems are not a walk in the park, but they don't always have to be represented by the 'misery porn' often shown in the media.
Survivors - whether from human trafficking like our documentary, mental illness, sexual assault, domestic violence or any other kind of abuse -  are among the strongest and most beautiful people we know. 
This is why we want to make this film. A film about someone who's been through it, by someone who's been through it also.  And we want to share it with you to open a wonderful, sincere conversation.
With your help - we can do it



How The Money Will Help
We're hoping to raise £6,250 from this campaign, which will go towards the production (the shoot) of this film, including the cast, crew, camera & lighting equipment, costumes, props, transport and catering. We will also need some money for post-production, including editing, grading, sound design and music. And finally, we'll be putting the film on the film festival circuit for as many people as possible to see!
 

 
5% of funding from this campaign will go to the Amies Freedom Choir, an organisation working with survivors of human trafficking, a project set up by Pan Intercultural Arts, that uses the arts for social change by working with those on the margins of society.
Check out the perks we've got for you by clicking on them!


 

The Impact
This project will contribute to the mental health narrative. It will put survivors in a different light, as creators of their own script.

story:
Synopsis

In a town besieged by rolling airstrikes, a lonely grandmother discovers the will to live after an orphan boy sneaks into her home for safety. Their time together reveals a connection between two lost souls.  

 

Enter the World of Home

The setting of Home is meant to be both familiar and distant. Loosely based on the architecture of various locales around the world, Home is a foreign place lost in time, stuck between sunset and sunrise.


Concept Art: A rendition of the cityscape.


Concept Art: the alley Argo lives in at the beginning of the film.


Concept Art: A view of the lush garden on the balcony of Deborah's home.  


Concept Art: Deborah's Bedroom - a home steeped in faded memories. 

 

Meet the Characters

Argo: a filthy looking boy who we meet while rummaging for food in a dumpster. When a loud air raid siren goes off, rockets and mortars start to drop over the city. As he races for safety frantically, he discovers a house with a small hole in the wall. He dives in for safety. 

Deborah: a sweet grandmother who lives alone in a tiny home in the city. One day she spots something rustling between the plants on her balcony. Thinking it's a racoon, she repeatedly bonks the creature with her cane until it falls out of the plants. It's Argo! 

 

A Thesis Film in the Making

Home is Director and Co-Writer Marc Van Holt's thesis film, as he wraps up his final year of pursuing his master’s degree in Film and Television Production at University of Southern California. This film is inspired by his ambition to create art that serves as a form of escapism and entertainment for a new generation of children. Marc and team are collaborating to create the animated world of Home through storyboarding, artistic renderings, motion capture filming and much more. This is definitely something much more powerful when seen: check out our progress so far below! 


Storyboard Image: Argo emerges from his dwelling 


Storyboard Image: Argo hides in Deborah's Garden with Deborah about to enter 


Storyboard Image: Deborah tends to Argo's wounds 


Character Design: Initial renderings of Argo's image before a 3D Design. His name has evolved from Margo to Argo! 


Character Design: A very rough, 3D-animated model of Argo. Credit: Simon Burdick


Action Shot: Our team hard at work, deep in the technical process of building an animated world.

 

Meet the Team

 

 

 

 

 

The Inspiration and Process

Director and Co-Writer Marc is extremely passionate about using technology to tell stories. As a freshman in college, he was the first student to make a 3D short film in the history of the university. From there, his love for technology and visual effects (VFX) has only grown as he's progressed in his education and experience. He feels so lucky to be at such an amazing film school where he can draw upon the talent of his impressive classmates who are diligently working to bring Home to life as storyboarders, animators, artists, musicians and many other roles essential to producing an animated film. 

We are currently wrapping up pre-production, and excited to get rolling on production after many group brainstorms, critiques and enhancements from big picture concepts to the minutiae! Our next step is to do a motion capture shoot, using high tech suits on set to capture the subtlety of body movement. This will be used as a foundation for our animation. 

While this is Marc's thesis film for USC, in order to maintain all copyrights on the final production, we must raise money to cover all the costs. In addition, upon completion, we plan to submit the film to festivals in order to drive awareness and visibility for our film. You can find our timeline and budget breakdown below. 

Timeline

May 21-23 -- Principal Photography
May 24 - Aug. 28 -- Animation
Jun. 13 - Oct. 30 --  Effects, Lighting, Rendering, Compositing
Sep. 12 - Nov. 20 -- Picture Editing
Oct. 10 - Dec. 11 -- Post Sound
Dec. 18 -- Final Delivery

Budget

$5,750 - Crew
$3,000 - Motion Capture Location Rental
$1,000 - Marketing and Distribution
$675 - Catering and Craft Services 
$450 - Production Fees
$375 - Miscellaneous Fees
$320 - Hardware
$210 - Post Sound
$195 - Software
$115 - Transportation Fees
$410 - Contingency
$12,500 - Total

 

How Can I Support?

A Message from Marc

My motivation for Home stems from my sense of action and responsibility. Growing up in a war zone was nothing but traumatizing for me. Sadly, our world still seems locked in the vicious cycle of hatred, death, and destruction. My goal as a filmmaker and an artist is to create hopeful and positive stories to inspire a new vision for the future, but I need your help to turn this idea into a reality. Please know that ANY funds you have to donate are so appreciated, and I cannot wait to have you be part of this journey called Home.  On behalf of the entire team, I thank you for your generosity!

Donation Perks

**Everyone who donates will receive their names in the credits**

In addition, check out our donation perks that you can find on our page here! Click on the perk to learn more about the specifics of what is included for each monetary value. Perks include hand drawn pictures, virtual wrap party invitation, 3D model figurines of Argo or Deborah and much more! Thank you so much for donating and supporting our film. 

Social Media

Make sure to give us a follow on social media to stay updated on our progress with the film! 

Instagram: @HomeFilmUSC

Twitter: @HomeFilmUSC

Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/Home-Film-USC

story:
Transcendence - The Story of Adrien Costa 

A film by: Michelle Smith

Log line: 

"Seemingly out of nowhere,  Adrien Costa  - the rising golden child in American pro-cycling - leaves the sport, only to find himself stuck under a rock with his life on the line. Now, forced to let his mind and body slow down, he trades his wheels in for a climbing harness and sets out to redefine himself searching for balance and identity as an athlete in the sports he loves."

 

  • Adrien Costa was amassing an incredible resume as a pro cyclist emerging onto the world stage before the age of 20. But something was missing from his life, so Adrien decided to leave cycling in pursuit of mountain adventure.

 

  • As a cyclist, Adrien loved the mountain passes but was drawn to go beyond the road to experience the summits Continuing to push his limits, but now as a climber, Adrien lost a leg, and nearly his life, during a solo mission high in the Sierras.

  • Now, just two years after the accident, Adrien is honing an impressive talent an adaptive climber and alpinist. More importantly, he is finding clarity on what it means to be an athlete and a human being by giving back as an educator and life-coach.

 

Meet The Film Team

Adrien Costa // Film Subject

“As a climber with a prosthesis, there is a certain societal stigma that I aim to break. I hope to convey the simple message that it is not physical, but psychological limitations that stand in the way of our goals in any domain, and that there is always a way to adapt to any given situation. I hope to inspire folks to follow their dreams regardless of how audacious or improbably they may seem, whether it be in sport, career, or personal.” While pursuing his dreams and limits as a climber, Adrien recently founded Intent Education, a service built to provide a wide array of tutors and leaders with different academic and extracurricular specializations to offer youth K-12 the most well-rounded, and individualized educational experience possible.  IG: @costadrien 

 

Michelle Smith // Director

Transcendence is Michelle’s next chapter after her breakout festival film, The Frenchy. Similar to Adrien, Michelle has survived a near death experience resulting in rescue after a 60’ fall on the Grand Teton. Michelle is known for identifying truly unique subjects and bringing their stories to life. MichelleSCreative.com

 

 

Patrick Henner // Executive Producer

 

Patrick is a veteran collegiate track coach, currently at ASU. Among his accolades, he’s the first coach in college history to have four athletes break the 4:00 minute mile in the same race. Also an avid rock climber, Patrick became friends with Adrien in Joshua Tree. After the two shared several memorable adventures, Patrick called his former athlete, Michelle, to say, “You gotta make a film about this guy!”

 

The Impact

Film is a tool to engage, inspire, and help make a difference for an individual and community. Your contribution will help make this film possible! With your help we can pay for production costs, editing fees, and distribution.

story:
Message from the Director

My Mom was (and still is) a music teacher, and growing up my three siblings and I were constantly surrounded by music. The four of us all became musicians ourselves, and one of my sisters even became a music teacher, too. I know exactly how music education can affect a student, but more importantly, how that music teacher can affect them. 

My name is Michael D. Smith, or Mikey for short. I'm the writer and director of Skipping A Beat. This Fall, I'm going to be a senior at Montclair State University, and I chose to focus my senior thesis film on something that felt personal to me. I've been impacted by all of the music teachers in my life, as well as my filmmaking teachers (yes... even from high school). To be blunt, we've all had at least one teacher who impacted us profoundly. 

However, I can't make this film happen alone. With your contributions, we'll be able to bring Skipping A Beat to life. Here's how...

 

Budget Breakdown

Our goal is $2,250.00! Each of your kind contributions will be rewarded with a perk (those can be checked out below). Here's a breakdown of exactly where your money will be going:

  • $105 - Travel for cast and crew
    • Some of our cast will be taking the train to get to the set every day, and we'd like to cover these costs for them as it can quickly add up! This section will also cover public transportation for our crew members who are traveling long distances. 
  • $650 - Set locations 
    • Filming within a high school definitely comes with some costs! After deligating the days and times we need to be there, and arranging the permits, $650 is the apprporiate amount to pay for our locations! 
  • $600 - Production and set design
    • Although we are filming in a high school that has school supplies, there's still a lot that goes into designing a set. This money will allow our Production Designer to make it all look much more real and convincing! There is also a scene within a hospital room that we need to design. 
  • $145 - Hair, makeup, and costumes
    • Our actors have to look the part! 
  • $500 - Camera equipment
    • To make the film look the best that it can be, we have to rent additional lenses. This is definitely not cheap, but a decision we're happy to dedicate some of our campaign to. We want Skipping A Beat to be at its full potential!
  • $200 - Gear transportation
    • Getting the gear to and from the set is always a hassle, and can be a safety issue if not handled properly. Renting a truck to hold all of the gear will ensure its safety and ours. 

 

Risks & Challenges

Our biggest challenges really stem from the quality that we want to emulate on the screen. With the gear provided by Montclair State University, we are able to get a decent product using our collective creative minds. But we want more. We want to make an excellent product that I can confidently end my collegiate career with. When matched with excellent locations, gear rentals, production, and set design to decorate our locations with, it all adds up. I want to give this project everything I have, but I need just a little help to reach that goal.

 

Meet the Crew

Michael D. Smith is the driven and devoted Writer/Director of Skipping A Beat. He's written and directed many short films in the past, including his most recent piece "Nightmare News" which has been screened at three film festivals (so far...), and he's never afraid to be big and bold. Smith's ambitions are large, but don't let it make you sweat because he always pulls it off. 

 

Annie Fleisch is our wonderful and fearless Producer/Assistant Director. She has won countless awards at many prestigious film festivals as well as commanding crews of 20+ people all leading with kindness and efficiency. Don't let her 5' 1'' height fool you, she gets the work done!

Dylan J. Tollefson is our talented and clever Director of Photography. He has over 30+ narrative short films under his creative belt as well as music videos, docs; you name it Dylan's shot it. He truly makes the frames you see shine in ways nobody else can.

 

A. Roux Tabor is our thoughtful and innovative Casting Director. She has worked with numerous different Directors to find the perfect cast for their movie. She sees something in actors that others don't, and that level of commitment and talent is unmatched.

 

Zach Miller is our gifted and inventive Production Designer. Zach really brings boring and dull sets to life through the use of color, set design, and form. His resume is loaded with set building, decorating, props and so much more. He really is the everyman that every production needs.

 

Jules Santamauro is our strong and visionary Editor. As someone who writes as well as edits films, she knows the importance of the editing process as it's the final step in a long journey. Her awards and screenings stack high off the ground as she continues to impress people with her creativity and unique perspectives.

 

Casey Gorab is our devoted and brilliant Composer. She has composed for almost every different type of music you can think of. Musicals, classical music, film compositions, as well as her own original music. She can sing, dance, and compose. She truly is the complete package that we need for this monster of a jazz film.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We don't all have extra money, and that's okay! If you can't contribute with your dollars, you can contribute with your words. Reshare and spread the word about our campaign so we can make, Skipping A Beat possible! 

Thank you for taking the time to read our campaign, and I hope you consider contributing!
story_txt:
Message from the Director
My Mom was (and still is) a music teacher, and growing up my three siblings and I were constantly surrounded by music. The four of us all became musicians ourselves, and one of my sisters even became a music teacher, too. I know exactly how music education can affect a student, but more importantly, how that music teacher can affect them. 
My name is Michael D. Smith, or Mikey for short. I'm the writer and director of Skipping A Beat. This Fall, I'm going to be a senior at Montclair State University, and I chose to focus my senior thesis film on something that felt personal to me. I've been impacted by all of the music teachers in my life, as well as my filmmaking teachers (yes... even from high school). To be blunt, we've all had at least one teacher who impacted us profoundly. 
However, I can't make this film happen alone. With your contributions, we'll be able to bring Skipping A Beat to life. Here's how...
 

Budget Breakdown
Our goal is $2,250.00! Each of your kind contributions will be rewarded with a perk (those can be checked out below). Here's a breakdown of exactly where your money will be going:

$105 - Travel for cast and crewSome of our cast will be taking the train to get to the set every day, and we'd like to cover these costs for them as it can quickly add up! This section will also cover public transportation for our crew members who are traveling long distances. 

$650 - Set locations Filming within a high school definitely comes with some costs! After deligating the days and times we need to be there, and arranging the permits, $650 is the apprporiate amount to pay for our locations! 

$600 - Production and set designAlthough we are filming in a high school that has school supplies, there's still a lot that goes into designing a set. This money will allow our Production Designer to make it all look much more real and convincing! There is also a scene within a hospital room that we need to design. 

$145 - Hair, makeup, and costumesOur actors have to look the part! 

$500 - Camera equipmentTo make the film look the best that it can be, we have to rent additional lenses. This is definitely not cheap, but a decision we're happy to dedicate some of our campaign to. We want Skipping A Beat to be at its full potential!

$200 - Gear transportationGetting the gear to and from the set is always a hassle, and can be a safety issue if not handled properly. Renting a truck to hold all of the gear will ensure its safety and ours. 


 
Risks & Challenges
Our biggest challenges really stem from the quality that we want to emulate on the screen. With the gear provided by Montclair State University, we are able to get a decent product using our collective creative minds. But we want more. We want to make an excellent product that I can confidently end my collegiate career with. When matched with excellent locations, gear rentals, production, and set design to decorate our locations with, it all adds up. I want to give this project everything I have, but I need just a little help to reach that goal.
 

Meet the Crew

Michael D. Smith is the driven and devoted Writer/Director of Skipping A Beat. He's written and directed many short films in the past, including his most recent piece "Nightmare News" which has been screened at three film festivals (so far...), and he's never afraid to be big and bold. Smith's ambitions are large, but don't let it make you sweat because he always pulls it off. 
 

Annie Fleisch is our wonderful and fearless Producer/Assistant Director. She has won countless awards at many prestigious film festivals as well as commanding crews of 20+ people all leading with kindness and efficiency. Don't let her 5' 1'' height fool you, she gets the work done!

Dylan J. Tollefson is our talented and clever Director of Photography. He has over 30+ narrative short films under his creative belt as well as music videos, docs; you name it Dylan's shot it. He truly makes the frames you see shine in ways nobody else can.

 

A. Roux Tabor is our thoughtful and innovative Casting Director. She has worked with numerous different Directors to find the perfect cast for their movie. She sees something in actors that others don't, and that level of commitment and talent is unmatched.
 

Zach Miller is our gifted and inventive Production Designer. Zach really brings boring and dull sets to life through the use of color, set design, and form. His resume is loaded with set building, decorating, props and so much more. He really is the everyman that every production needs.
 

Jules Santamauro is our strong and visionary Editor. As someone who writes as well as edits films, she knows the importance of the editing process as it's the final step in a long journey. Her awards and screenings stack high off the ground as she continues to impress people with her creativity and unique perspectives.
 

Casey Gorab is our devoted and brilliant Composer. She has composed for almost every different type of music you can think of. Musicals, classical music, film compositions, as well as her own original music. She can sing, dance, and compose. She truly is the complete package that we need for this monster of a jazz film.

Reshare and spread the word about our campaign so we can make, Skipping A Beat possible! Thank you for taking the time to read our campaign, and I hope you consider contributing!

story:
What's Even Happening?

We are raising funds for the production of a short film about two queer women that doesn't end in queer death, in trauma porn, or any of the other negative tropes attached to queer storytelling. This short is about love and accountability. And it's called eXcape. It's a pun. You'll get it when you read this:

They're eXes who can't esCAPE each other. eXcape. Get it?!

Who Are We?

We are Taylor (writer) and Molly (director), and we are two queer femme artists who want to tell queer femme stories that break with/expand upon genre.

Combined, we have many years of experience writing, performing, and directing poetry, theater, and music, and we are now exploring our storytelling in a new form: film.

Here are the people who make up our brilliant team: 

Writer: Taylor Steele

Director: Molly Rose Heller

Cast: Lindsley Howard and Mariah Sanchez

Producer: Isabel Lopez 

Producer: CNT Productions

Director of Photography: Ben Duff

 

What Do We Even Need?

We are hoping to raise $3100. 

While we are relying a lot on the kindness of our communities (i.e talented people volunteering their time and resources), we also recognize the necessity to pay our cast and crew for their work and ensure they have everything needed to do their jobs well. 

No donation is too small to help us bring this story to life. 

Here's a little breakdown of how we will use secured funding:

Cast & Crew - 35%

Post-Production - 30%

Misc. (+ Indiegogo fees) - 20%

Rental Equipment - 15%

 

Any other ways to help?

We understand that this is...A Time™, so we understand if you can't financially contribute. If you still wanna support this queer li'l love story, you can spread the word: share this campaign on social media, text it to friends, make some noise in the comments when you see it online!

We can't wait to share this process with you!

Weird, the door just opened...

story:
Yelling at each other isn't working. Ignoring each other isn't working. I am creating this documentary to try and bridge the growing gap in our country so that we can remember how to talk to each other with respect. Because if we don't, the Ship of State is going to sink with ALL of us trapped onboard.

WE DID IT! 
The project fully funded, but if you click the perks you still can participate until the movie is finished!

The last few weeks have shown us that people are so fed up with injustice and systemic racism and oppression they’re ready to march in the streets. 

Good. 

It’s also made it abundantly clear just how far the roots of oppression reach down into the fabric of this country, and how hard some people will fight to keep them from being uprooted. 

There are, however, some good people out there who just don’t understand what’s happening in the world, or how we came to be here. And until we understand that, it’s impossible to find a way forward that works for everyone. 

Hopefully, you watched my video above with my nice shiny studio setup, but here’s the simplest taste I can give of what it feels like to be Black in America in 2020. 

 

My name is B. Dave Walters, and I say words about things. I am a filmmaker, writer and screenwriter mostly known for my work in the diversity and inclusion segment of the Tabletop gaming space. You may have seen me recently speaking on a number of panels about Black Lives Matter, and where we go from here.

However, I am first and foremost a Black man in America, which is basically like being a Black bear in America.  I’ve spent years writing about racism and inequality, and how to heal it and I recently returned to making videos on the topic. 

Back in 2016 after the deaths of Philando Castille and Alton Sterling, I took to writing about what it’s like to be Black and that was the birth of the "Dear America, From A Black Guy" series. Four years later, everything I said here is truer than ever: 

Dear America, From A Black Guy Part 1

Dear America, From A Black Guy Part 2


The simple answer is: I am asking you to help me do this work on a much higher level: 

Here is a Youtube playlist of my recent videos on the George Floyd Protests and Black Lives Matter.

I have created this project as a flexible funding goal; I will continue doing this work no matter what. My intention is to be able to make a documentary that explains three basic things: 

  • How systemic racism and inequality have built the world we live in. Little things like how slavery was never actually abolished, which once you understand that, things like the school-to-prison pipeline, and ‘war on drugs’ are revealed to be as insidious as they were always intended to be. 
  • Why ‘good people’ do racist things. Why your aunt feels the need to keep posting ‘All Lives Matter’ or your racist uncle hasn’t missed church in 20 years and is OK with kids in cages. And more importantly how something called ‘moral framing’ can help you reach him. 
  • The need to actually listen to each other with respect. I hosted a radio show for 7 years, I know how to talk into the void.  My goal is to engage with people I disagree with in order to try and find some sort of common ground.. 

Because if we don’t find a way to communicate openly with each other, and respectfully disagree when necessary the planet is doomed.  Right now a pandemic is spreading because some people would rather ‘own the libs’ than wear a mask.  They’d not just rather die they’d rather kill because of ideology, and that my friends is INSANE.  It has to stop, and we have the power to make a difference. 

 

As I said in the video above, $100,000 is the minimum for a full-length documentary; any less than that will still be dedicated to creating revolutionary digital content aimed at advancing the national conversation on race and justice. 

Documentary film making is still film making, and as such has four main phases:
Pre-Production, where we cover things like:
*Script writing - yes, documentaries have scripts!
*Creative concept - EXACTLY what are we going to feature, and what are we going to say? *Meetings and research - the past is murky and the present is complicated; we need to be accurate.
*Location scouting + permits: If the COVID-19 pandemic breaks, we’ll need permission to go places! 

Production, where we actually make the movie!
*Video equipment - better equipment means a better looking final product.
*Professional crew - I literally can’t do it all alone! I know a lot of people and can call in some solids to get good deals, but I need to pay people for their time and expertise.
*Studio rental, props, set design - we’re bound to outgrow my home studio pretty quickly! *Actors, on-camera talent, voice overs - dramatic recreations, etc. 

Post-Production, the most important and most often overlooked part of film making:
*Transcription of interviews - we’ll be recording a LOT of interviews, and someone has to write that all down.
*Logging of footage - keeping track of everything we shoot, and where it fits into the film (or Director’s cut).
*Stock footage and production music
*Graphics and animations - if I have ONE WISH we’ll be able to start our movie with something that tells the history of racism in America like this

 

COULD YOU IMAGINE THAT? 

Distribution, releasing the film into the wild:
*Duplication - blu-ray is still a thing!
*Compression for internet usage

 

People are in pain.  People are dying, and maybe we can help.

I don’t have any illusions that one documentary is going to fix all our problems. But if we can manage to open one person’s mind or spark some new conversations, our work will be done. 

Save one person, save the world!  

Risks & Challenges:

We think the time for this story is now, and we are committed to making the best film we can as quickly as possible. That said, documentary is an art, not an exact science, and there could be some bumps along the way. If production obstacles cause delays, that could mean that we get the film out to you, our backers, later than anticipated. 

However, we’ll be pumping out content all along the way. The protests are going, the election is four months, and unarmed black people are still getting murdered by the police. Now is not the time for silence! 

Please support this project if you can, and even if you can’t: Please signal boost!

story:
History has taught us the rigor of the youth in transforming society into a system that is progressive, receptive and sensitive to injustices oppression. Now it's our time to continue the legacy of the youth and the new leaders of the society. 

We resonates with every people who fought over fear and thrived in the reign of terror, attacks on human rights, military abuse, and threats on press freedom.

*This documentary has begun production and will only be receiving money from the campaigner's family and friends.  Thank you for your understanding.

Now it's our time to continue the legacy of the youth and the new leaders of the society. We resonates with every people who fought over fear and thrived in the reign of terror, attacks on human rights, military abuse, and threats on press freedom.*This documentary has begun production and will only be receiving money from the campaigner's family and friends.  Thank you for your understanding.

story:
Cara (9) awakens in a dark hospital room with no memory of how she got there.  Just at the edge of her peripheral vision in a large chair sits James, an oppressive figure made of shadows, and two unfamiliar twin girls. James moves towards Cara but is interrupted when Nurse Never opens the door and blinds, flooding the room with light and causing James and the girls to disappear. Nurse Never ignores Cara when she asks about how she was admitted to the hospital. That night, James attacks Cara again, but this time she narrowly manages to save herself by pulling off her heartbeat sensor and triggering an alarm. Cara closes her eyes, but when she opens them, it’s the next morning, and she is surrounded by a weeping young woman and two elderly women she doesn’t recognize. Nurse Never brings in food for Cara, but just before blindly taking a bite of it, Cara realizes the plate is full of fat white maggots. When Cara refuses to eat, the nurse, the young woman, and a guard from the hall hold her down and force-feed her, but she manages to grab a flashlight from the guard in the commotion. When she wakes up that night, she goes to rip out her IV but is stopped by a young nurse who shows her how to do it the right way, then disappears before Cara can thank her. Cara moves down the hallway, hunting for James, who leads her to a bathroom. While searching for James with the light, Cara looks in the mirror and sees an old woman staring back at her. Cara realizes that she’s not a little girl, but a Dementia patient in hospice. She sees that the two visitors from before were her daughter and older sisters, and James is a manifestation of her long-dead abusive father. James breaks Cara’s flashlight, but just as James is about to overcome her, Cara remembers the young nurse from before is her as well and comforted by the fact that she can rely on her own strength, she starts to fight back. Suddenly, Nurse Never opens the door, and when the room is filled with light, Cara sees it was all a trick of her mind once again. Nurse Never takes her back to her room, and for a moment we think that Cara might have lost all of those realizations once again, but when Never leaves the room for a moment, Cara moves James’s chair out of the dark.

I wrote Sundown after spending some time living with and helping take care of a family friend diagnosed with Alzheimer’s. Although most people know generally about Alzheimer’s, other forms of Dementia, and their most well-known symptoms, few people have lived with the day-to-day struggles of caring for someone suffering from those diseases. Furthermore, the degenerative nature of these diseases makes it impossible for those suffering from it, to communicate their experience in a way other people can fully understand, making it even more difficult for both strangers and caretakers alike, to empathize with the patient’s experience. Normally ordinary tasks, like feeding someone, or bathing them, can become exhausting battles with someone who you’re doing everything you can to love and care for. Throughout my life, I have dealt with disabilities that other people have had difficulty understanding. For that reason, I wanted to tell a story that dealt with the everyday horrors of Dementia without sugarcoating them while still showing empathy for and inspiring hope in people dealing with the disease and their caretakers and loved ones.

story:
What in the world is this film?!

After a traumatic breakup with his college sweetheart, a film student dedicates his thesis documentary to discovering the key to love from a collection of married couples, but he will soon uncover that ain't nuthin' holy bout these matrimonies.

 

Milo's Documentary Crew

A recent breakup has him on edge, but he's a lover at heart. MILO is a boyish character who's in his beginning stages of manhood. He is a little naive and irrational sometimes, but his youth really breathes life into the story. Watching him fail and get into sticky situations really makes us laugh and reminds us of our silly youthful mistakes. He's talented depending on who you ask, but most importantly, Milo is a risk taker. He's making this documentary to show the world the key to love, but really, it's a coping mechanism for him to visit these couple who he thinks can help show him what love truly means.

 

CAMERON and DALLAS have never thought of working on a film crew in their life. They're just doing it to support Milo because he's too broke to hire a real crew. But they will soon be glad they did as they are about to experience a whole lot of craziness.

 

The Moore's

MR. MOORE is wheelchair-bound war veteran who's full of dry humor and witty remarks that his wife loves. It's obvious that the war didn't kill his spirit, instead helped him mature as a man. He's probably only as easy going as he is because he has no idea his wife is a closeted cougar. 

Say what you want about MRS. MOORE, but she loves her husband dearly. She really does. And it's clear that they love each other... But she has needs, okay?! She's too good looking for her age to be in a sexless marriage just because her husband decided to be an American patriot. And if she preys on young men then so be it. All that matters is that Mr. Moore has no freakin' idea.

 

The Ramirez's

After her controlling husband's "unexpected" death, all the controlling is in MRS. RAMIREZ's hands now and she loves it. She couldn't be happier as his necrophiliac wife. She's deep in denial of her situation though, so be very very weary of what you say to her. To her, he's still alive. The neighbors are still suspicious that she's responsible for MR. RAMIREZ's death, but the police just couldn't quite prove it.

 

The Portman's (...kind of)

DUMB and his partner in home burglary, DUMBER, are about to be caught in the wrong place at the right time as they will have to convincingly act as the Portman's in order to avoid a prison sentence.

 

Comps

 

Meet the filmmakers!

I am T. HAYES a multi-award-winning-filmmaker and founder of Shock Jockey Films. I wrote and shall direct Anywhere But New York. It will be my final short film I make in Texas before I make the big leap to Los Angeles and pursue my career in film. If you guys could help me get this film made, I shall be eternally grateful. Nothing means more to me than making movies.

 

STEPHEN CHINN is a multi-talented filmmaker of music videos, documentaries, photography, and graphic design. Visit his website! www.thecreativeexperience.online 

 

Our Producer, MERRITT JOHNSON is experienced in the production and management of the film and music industry. A double-threat!

 

Our other Producer, JARED SAFFOLD, is killing it in the film industry at the moment, having worked at DreamWorks,  Television Academy, and NBC.

 

What We Need & What You Get

Our goal is to raise $10,000! Wow! Yikes! We know, lol! 

Look, this could have easily been a more expensive film, but we've already cut as many corners as we can. Trust me on this. I don't want to be on here asking for 10k, but my Producers are saying 10k, and that's just what we gotta do.

Don't worry! There's some perks in it for you as well! You can check those out on your right hand side of the screen. Also, if there's any money left over, I will find a way to reimburse you big spenders. Scouts honor. I didn't make it to Eagle Scout, but I was pretty darn close enough for trustworthy's sake.

 

The Impact

This film should start a conversation around relationships. Various opinions are thrown around on what life and relationships should look like, but who’s to say who’s formula is correct. Different strokes for different folks. What may work for you won’t work for others, especially in a setting as intimate as a marriage. To think of us human beings as so simple that there's only one way a marriage should work greatly undermines the complexities of the individual. Surface level topics are easy to control and make rules for, but there’s nothing shallow about love. That’s for sure.

In all honesty, the comedy genre is sort of dying. You see it. I see it. We all know it's true. If I could make any other genre of film, I would, but I can't. God gave me the voice of comedy, and I have to use my gift to improve the world in any way I can. This filmmaking journey is taking me places I never thought I could go, but I can never do it without the support of others. Together, we can be a reviving force to the comedy genre.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word!

Share the link!

Please.

We beg you.
story_txt:
What in the world is this film?!
After a traumatic breakup with his college sweetheart, a film student dedicates his thesis documentary to discovering the key to love from a collection of married couples, but he will soon uncover that ain't nuthin' holy bout these matrimonies.
 
Milo's Documentary Crew

A recent breakup has him on edge, but he's a lover at heart. MILO is a boyish character who's in his beginning stages of manhood. He is a little naive and irrational sometimes, but his youth really breathes life into the story. Watching him fail and get into sticky situations really makes us laugh and reminds us of our silly youthful mistakes. He's talented depending on who you ask, but most importantly, Milo is a risk taker. He's making this documentary to show the world the key to love, but really, it's a coping mechanism for him to visit these couple who he thinks can help show him what love truly means.
 

CAMERON and DALLAS have never thought of working on a film crew in their life. They're just doing it to support Milo because he's too broke to hire a real crew. But they will soon be glad they did as they are about to experience a whole lot of craziness.
 
The Moore's

MR. MOORE is wheelchair-bound war veteran who's full of dry humor and witty remarks that his wife loves. It's obvious that the war didn't kill his spirit, instead helped him mature as a man. He's probably only as easy going as he is because he has no idea his wife is a closeted cougar.
