story:
Summary

Welcome to the Wilbur crowdfunding page! We are a group of third year students embarking on our Final Major Project. 

Wilbur follows an elderly man who struggles with developing dementia. Having recently lost his wife, he continues his day to day life with the aid of his daughter, until one day she doesn’t arrive. Due to the nature of his condition, he quickly forgets that she was meant to be coming in the first place and goes about his day with difficulty.

Our group have decided to make this film because so many lives are affected by Alzheimer's and dementia. However, the cases we have known often involve someone who can rely on family or friends to look out for them... but what about the people who are left without such a person? 

We want to raise awareness that some people are oblivious to the fact that they may need care and as a result, do not speak out. We also wish to draw attention to the value of carers and the importance of family support to the elderly.

 

From The Director

My crew and I are striving to create the best work of our careers and this drive is what has inspired us to keep going- even when times are so uncertain. We have a need to tell this story as the loneliness of frailty and old age continues to be a serious issue regardless of what else is going on in the world.

It has been a difficult year for everyone, but with your support we will be able to get our message out there and spread awareness of the issues surrounding Dementia.

 

Where's My Money Going?

We aim to raise £2000 which will support us in paying for: location, actors, catering, production, design, travel and, hopefully, a fundraiser screening event in May 2021. If we can reach our goal, this will allow us to access locations, actors and props that are in keeping with the story and mood of the film.

We would be immensely grateful if you would be able to donate to our appeal, however there are other options if you are unable to do so (see below).

In addition we do have some perks available if you wish to donate a set amount.

Risks & Challenges

As I'm sure you're aware, the pandemic has had an affect on the operations of many things. However we are determined to meet our goal of filming in the Spring. We will adhere to the COVID guidelines throughout the process of filming: social distancing, wearing masks, etc.. 

We already are in contact with a location that are willing to let us film, which we are very happy about (as this is one of the hardest things to find in the current climate). We also have some fantastic actors who are on board with the project and invested in the story. To be respectful of these amazing individuals, we will all be making sure to use every  means possible to keep the location clean. The crew will also be consistently using hand sanitiser and washing hands where possible. Additionally, only the crew that are essential to each scene will be in the room so as to minimise crowding. The interior scenes will also be well ventilated.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that it is a difficult time for everybody, so if you are unable to donate, please share and spread awareness of us on Social Media. We'll be extremely grateful for your support, whatever form it comes in.

Follow Us! Instagram & Facebook:
@wilburshortfilm

story:
As a thank you for your support we created many perks. Each of them comes with the digital download of the movie. Thank you for your support!

We shot the concept trailer over one weekend with no money. It is to show you how the film will be like. Now we have to raise money to shoot the whole 90 minute feature film.

Join us and become a part of 'Thieves In The Night'! 

‘Thieves In The Night’ is an intense thriller with an element of dark humor. 

One of the goals of this film is to make every character interesting and relatable - the family and the thieves alike. The viewers will find themselves rooting for different characters. The audience will be fully invested in the characters, so the inevitable consequences will hit them even harder.

We love movies that are suspenseful, but also have a sense of humor. If we can have a laugh from time to time in a serious suspenseful film, we had a good time at the movies.  

We deliberately chose a one location setting and a limited cast, trapped together, so we can explore these characters and also keep the production costs low.

We kept the page count under one hundred to maintain a fast pace, to avoid fillers and keep the audience on the edge of their seats. The script already won an award for best thriller.

If you like this concept of a home invasion thriller with a touch of Tarantino/Cohen Brothers and a bit of Spaghetti Western sprinkled over it, this is for you.

Synopsis

After a botched heist, three thieves break into a supposedly empty house to wait out the night. When they discover a family inside, one wants to get rid of the witnesses, one has an eye for the teenage daughter and one tries to get everyone safely through the night. But the biggest threat is yet to arrive ...

Cast

Meet our fantastic cast. 

Director of Photography

Matthew Button started his career in the lighting department for live and filmed shows. His work earned him world class lighting design awards and he has been nominated many times. His live design work gave him the fortune to work with clients from The Chemical Brothers, Jay Z to Beyoncé to Mercedes.

Button has had extensive work within commercials as a lighting designer, and within lighting departments on large scale films. Recently he worked on Transformers: The Last Knight, Kingsman: Golden Circle and War Machine starring Brad Pitt.

When and Where?

We are shooting throughout February 2022 on The Isle of Wight (UK).

What will the money be spent on?

  • The rent for the location.
  • Housing for the cast and crew
  • Food for the cast and crew
  • Paying the actors
  • Equipment and props

The more money we raise, the more of a beautiful film we can make.

story:
Welcome to the official crowdfunding campaign for...

 

WELCOME TO THE GAYEST PLACE ON EARTH follows the history and legacy of Parliament House, one of the most iconic gay nightclubs in America.

For any LGBTQ+ person living in central Florida, Parliament House has been a place where generations of queer-identifying people could find entertainment and community without the prejudices of the outside world. With a hotel, restaurant, pool, sit-down theatre, several bars, lakefront views, extravagant sets and more extravagent drag shows, Parliament House's original location was a premiere gay destination. Unfortunately, in November of 2020, the original location of 45+ years was shut down and demolished. While Parliament House is, fortunately, making its comeback in downtown Orlando, its initial closure signals a decline in safe nightlife for queer-identifying people across the country. 

This documentary will be told through personal interviews, archival media, and cinematic dramatizations.

 

This documentary is a project by Lightup Shoebox Productions.

As part of Lightup Shoebox Productions, the producers/directors (and romantic partners) Clark Levi and Joshua C. Thomas are queer filmmakers and theatre artists from central Florida who strive to tell culturally diverse and inclusive stories. We believe authenticity is vital to great storytelling. WELCOME TO THE GAYEST PLACE ON EARTH is no exception to this belief.

CLARK LEVI (Co-Producer/Co-Director/Editor)

Clark Levi is an arts activist, director, devisor, producer, and arts administrator. He founded Lightup Shoebox to uplift marginalized voices from central Florida and beyond through film, theatre, and all kinds of media. Aside from co-creating Oh Boy: Poverty, Polyamory, and All My Poor Decisions in Between with Alex Hill, Clark is the recurring editor of the web series UNMUTED Stories with Beth Marshall Presents. Clark is also collaborating with local organizations, including Orlando Fringe, on Diversity, Equity, and Inclusivity (DEI) initiatives.

JOSHUA C. THOMAS (Co-Producer/Co-Director/Camera Operator)

Joshua C. Thomas is an award-winning screenwriter and producer. With Clark Levi and Alex Hill, he co-produced Oh Boy: Poverty, Polyamory, and All My Poor Decisions in Between. Oh Boy... streamed through the Orlando Fringe Festival and will be streaming through the Rochester Fringe Festival in September 2021. As he is co-producing WELCOME TO THE GAYEST PLACE ON EARTH, Joshua is also the cinematographer for his first narrative feature Leviticus, based on the award-winning stage play. 

Clark and Joshua hope to tell Parliament House's powerful story of survival and advocacy in a way that values the safety and community that queer nightclubs should uphold. 

 

We are ready to make this movie, but we need your help to make it as cinematic and ready for the big screen as we possibly can! Funds from Indiegogo will be used for:

  • High-quality photography and cinematography.
  • High-quality sound recording equipment.
  • High-quality lighting kit.
  • The remastering of archival media.
  • Film festival and VOD distribution.

 

The story of Parliament House, and the current turbulence of queer safe spaces, is vital to share with the world. Film is the perfect medium to reach a global audience. Achieving this goal relies on the success of this campaign.

 

Not a single dollar will go unappreciated. 

For your generous contribution, we have multiple exclusive perks ranging from personal thank you messages all the way to exclusive merch and credits in the final cut of the film.

As you plan your contribution, please see the perks listed on this page. We want to reward our investors for their patronage, whether it’s $5 or $500.

 

Whether you’re able to contribute money or not, there’s more than one way to support our campaign. 

We are exclusively crowdfunding through this official Indiegogo campaign. You’re able to share this campaign across all social media platforms, directly from this page.

You can also share our campaign directly with your friends, families, and local drag artists through word-of-mouth. 

And be sure to follow “Lightup Shoebox” on Facebook and Instagram to stay updated on this film and future projects.

story:
Eat the Turnbuckle is a Philly based Ultra Violent, Death Match Wrestling, Rock and Roll band.  We are currently working on a documentary entitled..

STABBED IN THE FACE: The Rise and Fall of the Worlds Most Violent Band

We went from playing empty shit hole bars to ending our career at Wacken in Germany in front of thousands of people. During that time we gathered hundreds of hours of footage, broken bones, gallons of spilt blood and a whole lot of stories. 

We've teamed up with the good people at Patchtown Films to help us create in great detail a raw uncensored behind the scenes account  of the rise and fall of the worlds most violent band, but we need your help...

This doc is going to cost upwards of $15,000 said and done (shooting new content, editing 100's of hours of footage, getting it to film festivals, streaming platforms, limited edition merch, booking a venue for the premier etc). We are ready to take on that financial burden but if you enjoyed what the band did and want to be a part of something very special to us, your contribution would be extremely appreciated. 

The documentary is already in the works and we are working very hard to have a finish date in sight, as of now it will be sometime in 2021. 

IF we hit our goal that would  be incredible and take care of a huge chunk of the expenses to make this happen. We have created a very unique incentive program but any financial assistance will help us out more than you know, even $1.

NOW IT'S YOUR TURN TO STEP IN THE RING!!

story:
TO DONATE:  FROM PHONE: Select a PERK from the list or scroll all the way to the end to make a custom donation of your choosing ("contribution").  FROM COMPUTER: Select a PERK from the list or click the "BACK IT" button next to the trailer. You can choose a perk or a custom donation ("contribution").   Thank you!

IF WE RAISE EVEN A SMALL CHUNK OF OUR GOAL that will help us get grants, loans, and investors! Help us get started :) by reaching 20-25k!

 

IT IS TIME. 

After many almost-but-not-quite film deals, we decided that we’re meant to film this ourselves! With full creative control and a kick-ass FEMALE-LED team!! And of course, our army of rad supporters, who we could not do any of this without! 

Help us be a voice for first-generation-ers everywhere. It’s our time! Time to laugh :)

Check out the fun perks that come with your donation!  CLICK THEM FOR DETAILS! → → → 

Take a look at the budget breakdown below to see where the funds go!

 

THE STORY 

Three first-generation girls sneak out to an all-American house party in 1999.

Based on the director’s experience growing up first-generation Syrian-American in Los Angeles. Cause (immigrant) parents just don’t understand :) But we love them anyway <3

Logline: 

Frustrated with their strict parents, Mariam (Lebanese), Naya (Indian), and Cho (Korean) decide to sneak out to an all-American house party and get the real high school experience they deserve – and soon realize they have no idea what they’re doing, or where they fit in.

VISIT OUR WEBSITE - firstgensmovie.com 

FOLLOW US FOR UPDATES! →  Instagram  →  Facebook →  Twitter

 

MEET YOUR TEAM 

Female-led and ready to rock! Check out this power team!

 

NAHREEN TARZI - Writer, Director, Producer, Dance Party Starter

Nahreen served as Head Writer of CBS Diversity Showcase 2018, was Head Writer at Frederator Networks for two years, and won BEST DIRECTION for directing the one-man-show "Fat, Gay, and Indian" at Crazy Woke Asians Festival 2019 (and the show won the entire festival and NBC Mentorship). She directed the 2-woman show "M.E So Funny" (Middle-Easterns So Funny), which featured in L.A. Weekly, showcased at Comedy Central Stage, was selected 3 years in a row at The Second City Diversity Festival, and was booked to perform at UC Riverside. She has also done freelance writing work for NICKELODEON, was an in-house writer for Moonbug Entertainment, and while there, was the studio's creative director for the animated show "Little Ruby Roo".

Nahreen's parents are immigrants from Aleppo, Syria, and this film is based on her experience growing up in Burbank. It is what she imagined WOULD HAVE happened if she had the guts to sneak out. She did not. Her dad had a 6th sense and she would have been caught! She did help another friend sneak out once, though.

More info on nahreentarzi.com

 

CARRIE DOUGHERTY - Producer, Diplomat, Headhunter, Hilarious Commentator 

Carrie has worked on multiple feature-length films, including The Art of Murder (2018) and Only Mine (2019), both produced by MarVista Entertainment. She brings vast production knowledge and is excited to produce this independent film. Additionally, Carrie comes with a deep-rooted career of studio-television production, with her most notable shows including: Who Wants to be a Millionaire (2020), Master Minds (2020), and Whose Line is it Anyway? (2019). These projects [and more] have influenced her mission to conduct highly-ethical and safe production, as well as, provide an unshakeable, business-minded spirit.

Carrie was born into a military family and spent her early childhood growing up in towns all across the United States, until settling in LA in 2015. From her exposure to the many unique and wonderful cultures within our vast country, she brought with her the vision to create passionate and intentional storytelling. "First Gens is a film that carries a deep and illuminating purpose: To bring us together by celebrating our differences."

 

MAGDOLEEN MELEKA - Story Consultant, Wicked Hoop-Wearer 

Magdoleen has served, worked, and supported immigrant communities for over 15 years.  While her career contexts have mainly comprised of the non-profit sector and educational institutions, she has always engaged in her love for people and the arts in her spare time. In every context, she is deeply committed to helping others articulate their true narrative and identify opportunities for thriving. 

She also has over 30 years of first-hand experience growing up in L.A. with Egyptian parents. She grew up speaking broken Arabic, listening to church hymns, and singing Mariah Carey - none of this has changed. As a first-gen herself and as a new parent, she is excited about the story and message that are shared in this silly-yet-sweet film. Oh, and, she has an unwavering appreciation for “gypsy earrings.”

 

VERONICA SMITH - Director of Photography, Great at Camera Jigs (see Instagram)

Veronica Smith is a Los Angeles-based cinematographer who has worked in the industry for 5 years. She has DP’d on a wide range of projects including several award winning short films, music videos, and commercials. She currently has two 2020 projects, "Madness" and "The Letter", running in festivals, with "Madness" already winning multiple awards. Veronica's true love is working on narrative films and she is constantly looking for new and exciting challenges. She is very excited to work with this incredible group of filmmakers!

Veronica grew up mainly in Northern Virginia and came to LA in 2016. She has family all across the country and has been lucky to travel to different places around the world. First Gens shows how we all value love and care deeply about the people in our life, no matter the background.

More info on veronicapsmith.com

 

MAGGIE HART - Co-Producer, Female Empower-er, Rockstar Multiple Hat Wearer

As a self-starter in the indie film world, Maggie Hart loves working with passionate female filmmakers. While attending film school and working full-time as a production manager, Maggie also wrote, directed, produced, and edited what would become her first feature, Impressions. After moving to Los Angeles, she did the same thing with a comedy web series called, “The Romantic Method,” and produced another feature film, Instructions For Living, which won the audience award at the Twin Cities film festival. In 2019 she relaunched Farsighted Creative, a production company dedicated to telling stories that empower women to make a cultural  difference. 

 

WHERE THE FUNDS GO

If you haven’t heard yet, making movies is EXPENSIVE. It takes a village, and we need to pay that village for their work :)

DEVELOPMENT – Legal fees, contract setup for all cast/crew, Casting Company, script clearance & rights clearance (rights for any lovely 90s references we are trying to show)

 

CAST – All cast members, from lead roles to one-liners to non-speaking roles!

 

PRODUCTION CREW – This is a big story with a lot of characters, so naturally, we need a lot of crew to help! Line Producer, Assistant Director, Script Supervisor, Production Designer, Production Assistants, Sound Mixer/Boom Operator and equipment, Music Supervisor, Makeup/Hair, Wardrobe, and the most important part – the Camera Department! Which includes the Director of Photography, Camera Operator, Grips, Gaffers, Lighting, Camera Assistants, and all the camera equipment rentals.  

 

PRODUCTION EXPENSES – All the stuff we need to buy for production! Set décor, props, wardrobe, any makeup/hair purchases, food catering, craft service snacks, location permits, hard drives for footage, script and schedule printouts (if not totally digital), and film liability insurance to cover safety and equipment.

 

PAYROLL – Basically the payroll taxes and fees! Since the new AB5 law in California no longer allows films to hire people as freelance, we must put all cast and crew on payroll, and therefore pay a hefty amount in payroll taxes. 

 

COVID-19 EXPENSES – Cause yes, it’s still here! This covers all the extra expenses related to COVID-19 safety measures – we need to make sure our cast and crew are safe and that we take proper precautions to protect everyone’s health. This includes PPE, sanitizing sets, hiring a Covid Compliance Officer, and making sure every single person gets tested properly for COVID-19.

 

POST-PRODUCTION – and this is low for post! It takes at least a couple of months (usually more) to edit a feature film. Then it takes even LONGER to do all the other stuff needed. So this covers: Editor, Music Composer, Music Rights Licensing fees, Audio Editing & Mixing, Sound Effects purchases, Stock Footage purchases, Color Correction, and Closed Captioning.

 

MARKETING/DISTRIBUTION – Let’s get this film out!! Set Photographer, movie poster, Film Festival fees, marketing & distribution fees, Errors & Omissions insurance required for distribution. 

 

And there’s probably some stuff we forgot to include. So much goes into making a film, and we’d love to make this one for you all to see! 

Stay tuned for updates, and can’t wait to make this in 2021!

 

FOLLOW US! →  Instagram →  Facebook→  Twitter

VISIT OUR WEBSITE - firstgensmovie.com

story:
Short Summary

Chainsaw Sally is a beloved indie-horror icon, who, as it would seem, is not quite done.  I'm JimmyO Burril and I, along with my wife April created Chainsaw Sally in the early 2000's.  The film Chainsaw Sally is out around the world.  We then decided to make a web series... before there was really such a thing.  Netflix and other streaming services were not streaming yet.  We came up with The Chainsaw Sally Show, which had two successful seasons.  Well, it's time to let Sally do her thing once more.  If you don't know Sally, was my answer to the question : What if Bruce Wayne was female, poor, and had no guidance what so ever.  That is Sally in a nutshell.   An unhinged,  five foot 3, vengeance machine.  Her idea of right and wrong may be a tad askew, but her chainsaw will sort it out.

What We Need & What You Get

We are hoping to raise as close to $20,000 as we can. Season 1 was done for almost no money.  All out of pocket.  Season 2 we made for $10,000 and the quality was very nice.  We would like to up the game as much as we can for actors, crew, equipment, and.... let's not forget effects.  Oh yes, there will be blood.   The more, the better.  It's that simple.

The Impact

Season 3 of the Chainsaw Sally Show is really being made on demand from the many fans around the world.  We are and have always been outsiders of the film industry.  We are punk rock, grind house lovers and just don't seem to fit with in the "Fraternity" as Herschell Gordon Lewis would call it.  We have been called the "First Family of Indie Horror" which was the best and favorite quote from any review.  This is a labor of love for us.... and we plan to give the Sally fans exactly the show they want.  A little horror / a little comedy / a lot of blood. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't afford to chip in, please share the hell out of our campaign.  Sharing is caring. :)

story:
Who We Are

AS I AM is the opening song in Jordon's recent EP release, CHROMA. Jordon has aimed to emphasis authenticity in his music - hitting the nail on the head time and time again. AS I AM is the follow-up project to PAINT ME HOWEVER, another powerful song from the EP that addresses the racial and social dynamics at play in our society.

Directing this music video is Jack Speer, a talented director from The University of Texas at Austin with demonstrated history of working on authentic and creative projects. 

We have a crew of experienced individuals that have devoted months of their time to prepare for this set. Our team, including myself, find efficient use of resources a priority in this project. We have created a detailed budget entailing the costs that are absolutely needed so that every penny is spent wisely. With your help, we will be able to purchase location permits, rental equipment, and post-production media that will only help us elevate the production quality of this project

 

What We Need & What You Get

What your contribution is going towards:

  • We are looking for $3,000 to help cover the expenses below (Organized from most essential to least)
    • One-day studio rental w/ smoke machine ($400)
    • Permit for rural field location. ($300)
    • Camera Lenses (Rental)  ($200)
    • Set building costs. (Wood, Metal, Rental Tools, etc.) ($750)
    • Wardrobe (Clothing, Makeup, Jewelry, etc.) 
    • Props ($200)
    • Transportation ($150)
    • Hiring of Actresses, Models, and Special Cast ($200)
    • Remaining funds are for compensating crew and cast for their time at $10/hr.

What you receive for your contribution:

  • $25 - A special thanks in the credits and 5  Behind-The-Scene photos.
  • $50 - Personalized thank you letter w/ exclusive CHROMA stickers.
  • $100 - Thank you video from Jordon, Jack, and Marcos along with exclusive CHROMA stickers.
  • $250 - Group Q&A opportunity with Jordon, Jack, and Marcos and exclusive Behind-The-Scene video footage.
  • $500 - Producer Credit and Group Q&A opportunity with Jordon, Jack, and Marcos including a 30-minute Video session with Jordan & Jack to learn more about the process and them! Exclusive Behind-The-Scene video footage included as well!

Even if we do not meet our goal, your contribution will still be very beneficial to the video. Your money will go towards the most essential items first!

 

Risks & Challenges

We have aimed to minimize our risk and challenges the best we can by making sure to take time to tediously plan every stage of the process. We have worked hard to locate all the items on our list and know the exact cost of the needed costs for our resources. 

With that said, we acknowledge things don't always go as planned so we have taken extra time to assess challenges we may face. Here are some things we have considered possible challenges:

  • Obtaining the needed extras for scenes that require 40+ people.
  • Transporting all the materials and crew to various set locations.
  • Due to a tight schedule, we are limited on time so we have only one day to reshoot any mistakes.
  • COVID-19 has increased costs for some resources, meaning that our resources are limited and access to some needed resources is largely based on funds available.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you are unable to contribute financially, we appreciate any support! You can help us out by sharing this fundraiser on your social media and with people you know! Thank you.

You can also support Jordon by checking out his new EP, Chroma - available on iTunes, Spotify, Tidal, and other platforms.

story:
Poster 2

An exciting tense social thriller that explores microaggressions and the responses it causes.

Synopsis

Keon is a bright young black man that deals with daily microaggressions from a local police officer and co-workers at his internship. His silent anger continues to boil until he gets an unknown caller buzzing his phone who relates to Keon until a casual conversation quickly turns into a dangerous situation when it’s revealed that the caller has a sniper trained on Keon and his co-workers. He forces Keon to make a choice that will define him forever.

Who We Are

We are a group of students in Vancouver Film School in the Film Production program who want to develop and share this story with people to spark a discussion about microaggressions for our final project: Words, the weight that people get them, and the reaction it causes.

We have a flexible goal of $3,000.00 that will go towards upping the production value of this film, as well as securing locations and production design. We have a variety of perks, including pdfs of the script, digital screener of the film, production binder, Director's Commentary, and more.

Risks & Challenges

Making movies is always a challenge, but we are hardworking passionate students with the support of our teachers who are film industry professionals.

The Impact

The Social Thriller genre has gained much popularity after Jordan Peele made the film Get Out, a film that both entertains and educates you on the realities of the world. We hope to do the same thing with this film.

Your contribution will help our team make a difference in the creation of this film, overcoming challenges that may occur when production starts this fall/winter.

Other Ways You Can Help

We appreciate every contribution and we understand that not everyone can contribute monetarily, but you can help us by using our hashtag #UnknownCallerFilm sharing the campaign of our project so that it reaches more people, or by sharing or social media page: @unknowncaller.film

We appreciate every contribution and we understand that not everyone can contribute monetarily, but you can help us by using our hashtag #UnknownCallerFilm sharing the campaign of our project so that it reaches more people, or by sharing or social media page: @unknowncaller.film

story:
Short Summary

Vanessa is a young, devoted and professional assistant. It doesn't matter if it's day or night, she is always ready to fix anything, always on the clock, never stopping. No job is too big or too hard for her. Except for Alan Rogers, who might be her biggest headache, but also the only one who can give her the answers she needs. Alan is a simple, middle-aged man. Nothing special about him. But life has funny ways of taking us from one place to another, and this is how the most regular human being ends up being the most important one under the care of Vanessa. 

Dawn is a story about finding ourselves and what drives us through life. Finding some meaning in our existence. The future is always moving, and only we can mould it for ourselves.

 

Our Budget

This is where your generous donation comes towards our ambition. Our current budget is £1,000 this is to go towards expenses, props, set and travel etc. 

When making the perks for anyone who donates to us, we wanted you to feel like you were part of this project, so alongside the posters and credits.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We completely understand if you're unable to donate to the project, but a share does not cost anything and is a massive help towards the project!

 

Thank you for for your time,

Dawn productions cast and crew x

story:
3 Short Films

This year, I will be creating 3 short films to enter into festivals and to help me move forward in my film career.

The first film is called "Six Strings" 

It's a story about three guitar players that sell their soul to the devil for Love, Money, & Fame. It's starring  three amazing actors/musicians and a wonderful cast of supporting talent.

I Need Help!!!!

Thank you for helping me fund my goals!

  • Your contribution will go 100% into making three short films and bringing them to festivals.
  • Check out the cool perks to become a part of these projects!
  • If the monetary goal is not met, the rest of the money will come straight out of my college savings, so help me not stress out my Grandma!

Why Support Lori Mae?

You are helping establish me as an up and coming filmmaker! 

  • I am proud of the work that my cast and crew are doing on these three projects and I want to be able to enter into as many film festivals as possible.
  • "My Soldier" was my first short film that I made when I was eleven. I entered it into Indie Fest USA International Film Festival as an adult and it was nominated for Best Short Film and I won for Best Up and Coming Director.

Risks & Challenges

It's scary for a young girl to say they want to be a screenwriter and film director. In this industry, I definitely need your help.

Other Ways You Can Help

You might not be able to contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Help me get the word out about my three short films that will come out this year!
  • Use the share tools that Indiegogo offers to share to your social media!

story:
Budget Breakdown (approx.)

     

     

    Equipment: Any equipment we currently do not have access to will be rented from rental houses. Equipment will range from camera/accessories, sound recording equipment and lighting.

    Locations: The location is currently being scouted. Don't Forget to See Your Father takes place over the course of a day in a single location, so a cozy suburban home is vehemently being sought out!

    Art Department: Props, wardrobe, set dressings or anything related to the art department will be thrifted or bought used to cut down on costs.

    Insurance: A portion of the budget will be put toward insurance to protect the production, equipment and location.

    Food: A well fed and hydrated cast and crew is a happy cast and crew! A large part of our budget will be used for food and drink to get us through 3 days of shooting. We are in contact with a caterer who will ensure adequate meals are provided for everyone involved.

    Protective wear: As we all know, we are still in the midst of a global pandemic. Personal safety, proper food handling, and sanitation is of the utmost importance to us. Face masks and hand gel will be a constant presence on set.

     

    Timeline (approx.)

     

     

    The Impact

    It's been a tough year working remotely and individually. The pandemic has limited us in various capacities including access to resources, equipment, and most importantly, to one another. We are looking forward to working on something special together again and are relying on the support from our community to realize this project!

     

    We are grateful for any support. Whether it’s through  donations or sharing the link to our Indiegogo page, all help will be much appreciated!

     

    Follow our Instagram page @dftsyffilm

story:
Moe Promo Poster. (Subject to minor changes)

Moe T-Shirt Mockup. (Subject to minor changes)

Moe

Short Film: Runtime 15-20min

Directed By: Carson Rhodes

Coming: December 1st, 2021

Format: Digital/Festival release, up to 6k, Widescreen, 5.1 Surround Sound.

Short Summary

Moe is a story about a devoted father who will do anything to find his young daughter who is missing in the woods. After losing his wife to an illness not 2 years prior, the last thing he wants is to lose another part of his family. After an accidental fire displaces his 6-year-old daughter, Anna, it's up to this hunter trapper to track her down. Follow Moe as he treks horseback through a night filled with dangerous mountain ranges and forests searching for his beloved daughter. 

As the director, I think one of the greatest underlying themes of this film is the concept of giving up what is outside of our control. Now, giving up in any form or fashion is definitely not a story told very often for obvious reasons, but I don't think we should shy away from a story like that. I believe it is a story worth telling. Portraying a narrative that is told less often means we get new opportunities to display powerful, captivating stories in ways that people haven't experienced before. This very beneficial lesson is cleverly interwoven in the story of Moe.

From my perspective, the concept of giving up is this remarkable mystery that I don't understand. There almost seems to be a spiritual aspect in finding the things you're looking for just as soon as you stop looking for them. This strange concept is something I have observed with lost keys, cellphones, and even the simple things of life. In my experience, I have even seen some of the deepest lessons of life learned this way. The notion of letting go of control is something that audiences from all over the world can relate to, and it is a narrative that I am passionate about expressing through the story of Moe.

Where Does The Money Go

Here is a breakdown of the different categories:

  • Actors
  • Anamorphic lens rental
  • Light rental
  • Additional gear that we do not have in-house
  • Gas for actors and crew
  • Outdoor set construction
  • Props
  • Costumes
  • An original score mix
  • Practical Visual Effects (VFX)
  • Additional digital VFX that we can't do in-house
  • Film festival entry fees
  • And lastly, if there are any funds left over we would like to pay the crew members for their work

The Crew

Our crew is built up of a tight-knit community of talented individuals and students. The film is directed by Carson Rhodes. Edited by the skilled Will Vail. Our director of photography Connor Munch. Music by the amazing Kanoa Wolfe-Doblin. Additional VFX by Mutiny FX. And some more incredibly talented individuals working with Sound mixing, Arri lights, Steadicam, plenty of c-stands and grip tape, practical VFX, Incredible locations, and the Red Komodo 6k Camera.

Risks & Challenges

This project is my senior film to complete my degree and finish college, but it's also a film I'm passionate about. Like most passion projects they lack funds. We've decided that now is the best time to do the project, and we have most of it together. All we need now is the funds to reimburse our progress. This film is going to be made regardless of the funds we receive, but it would be very nice for the funds we receive to go towards paying back what we've already spent on the project. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Besides assisting in the funding of this film, the number one thing you can do to help us out is to tell others about this film project. If you liked it yourself or you can think of somebody who also might like it, share the project with them.

Also remember, Indiegogo has share tools that can make it easier for you to share this film with others on Facebook or wherever, but if that's not your thing then good ol' fashioned word of mouth would be much appreciated.

Again, thank you for checking out this campaign, see you on the big screen!

Again, thank you for checking out this campaign, see you on the big screen!

story:
June 2020. As communities seek to express their grief, horror, and outrage over the murder of George Floyd, a flotilla of police power assembles under an elevated transit line in West Philadelphia. An order is given (or is it?) to launch a chemical attack on the neighborhood. Within minutes, residential streets off the commercial strip are inundated with pepper spray and other toxins, choking residents. The event is considered unprecedented.

It is not.



May 1985.  A peaceful West Philly neighborhood is in the final showdown of an 11-year dispute. Five hundred policemen are barricaded in battle positions surrounding the three-story row house at 6221 Osage Avenue. They are held at bay by a small band of armed, mostly black pro-life activists known as MOVE. After a morning-long battle involving machine guns, explosives, and tear gas, the radicals remain defiant. The beleaguered Philadelphia police commissioner weighs his options and devises a new plan.

Philadelphia, the Birthplace of America and the City of Brotherly Love, is about to become the City that Bombed Itself.



Philadelphia Police Department drops the bomb from a helicopter. The MOVE home goes up in smoke. Of the 13 occupants, six adults and five children are killed. Within minutes, a raging fire consumes the neighborhood. By night's end, the death and devastation are unfathomable. Yesterday's peaceful, working-class neighborhood now looks like Berlin after the war: 61 homes destroyed, 250 people rendered homeless, a city filled with guilt and denial. 



The elements of the MOVE bombing feel quite familiar today. White police. Black victims. Horrifying violence. A shocked public watching on television. And yet, it was a different time, just before the tidal wave of cable TV and the national news networks. Philadelphia's nightmare was never disseminated as an American tragedy.

In the national narrative of civil rights landmarks, a broad gap exists between the turbulence of the 60s/early 70s and the LA riots of the early 90s. Philadelphia's MOVE bombing in 1985 is a forgotten chapter in this timeline. Enter PHILLY ON FIRE, a ghost story about the tortured soul of a modern city, from award-winning documentary filmmakers who believe that any road towards healing best runs through truth. 



PHILLY ON FIRE presents the unknown story of May 13, 1985, from those who lived it: Ramona Africa, the only adult MOVE member to escape the bombed house, and the only person sent to prison after the tragedy; Jim Berghaier, the hero cop who rescued 13-year-old Michael Ward (aka Birdie Africa), but whose life, marriage, and career careened out of control; and Andino Ward, Michael's father, united with Berghaier by the filmmakers in a remarkable moment of confession and redemption.



PHILLY ON FIRE excavates the historic and political roots of the MOVE tragedy—from the entrenched culture of the Philadelphia police and its enduring Frank Rizzo legacy, to the abrogation of decision making by Mayor W. Wilson Goode, the first African American to hold the position.  Deeply personal interviews with Goode and Police Lt. Frank Powell, the man who built the bomb, tell the story from the city's side.

Other perspectives come from Clifford Bond, the block captain who urged municipal action and lost his own home as a consequence. Journalist and Temple Professor Linn Washington, who has made MOVE his academic and research focus for 40 years. Mike Africa, Jr., who, born in prison to a MOVE member, has spent much of his lifetime working to free his parents from their life sentences.
 
"In PHILLY ON FIRE, you get characters who make you feel the human complexity of the conflict. The film paints those on all sides with broad brushstrokes of humanity, so that, in its raw storytelling power, it offers a roadmap to reconciliation." 

                                                                                - Larry Platt, Editor, The Philadelphia Citizen

Now more than ever, there is an urgency to acknowledge and understand the past. Told through the stories of those who experienced the MOVE bombing from extraordinarily diverse vantage points, PHILLY ON FIRE offers a pathway towards that understanding.



Creating independent films without the support of the studios or mainstream media is challenging and expensive. We’re up to the task. We know the importance of championing the stories that may otherwise go untold. We believe films such as this must be created with utmost integrity and respect. This means without the outside influence of studio heads, network executives, or advertisers. This is where you come in.

No contribution is too small. Every amount helps.





We used our own funds to shoot this film in its entirety. Now we need your help to finish it.

Post-Production includes assembling and editing the footage we captured, designing compelling graphics, creating a soundtrack, audio engineering, and color correction.

Marketing includes getting PHILLY ON FIRE out into the world: packaging the finished film and submitting it to film festivals, broadcasters, and reviewers. It also includes social media outreach.

Archival refers to the news footage we have to license for use in our film. Seeing is believing. Our story cannot be told without it. 





As an expression of our gratitude, we continue to update our donation perks. Please check out what's available today.

Perks are offered worldwide. If you'd like, you can donate without collecting a perk, or you can gift your perk to someone else.


 Ross Hockrow (Director) is a rising star in the documentary world, bringing his myriad filmmaking skills to a range of projects.  PHILLY ON FIRE is his latest effort, on which he is credited as director, DP, and editor.  He filled the same roles for Born Strong (Netflix) and Finding Giannis (TNT).  It was his work as a pioneer of DSLR filmmaking that led to a series of international tours teaching visual aesthetics.  Later, he wrote a book on visual storytelling theory and then led another teaching tour on editing techniques.  Hockrow’s other documentary films include The Fieldhouse (Discovery+), Valley of Sin (Fox), Women of Troy (HBO), We Town (Sports Illustrated/Amazon), Foreman (Epix/NBC Universal), An Act of Love (Apple), and Pot Barons of Colorado (MSNBC).  Previously, he wrote, directed, and edited scripted films. Ross is currently editing an independent feature documentary on Colin Kaepernick.  
 


 Bill Stephney (Producer) served as the chief executive for the firms Def Jam Recordings (which he helped develop into a multi-billion-dollar, youth lifestyle company), SOUL Records, and Stepsun Music. He produced artists ranging from Rock-And-Roll Hall of Fame Inductee Public Enemy to singer/actress Vanessa Williams. Bill has supervised music production for films including Boomerang, Be Be’s Kids, CB4, Clockers, and Shaft. He has worked as a media consultant and advisor for ESPN, Newark Venture Partners, National Public Radio, the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, MTV Networks, Miramax Pictures, USA Networks, and Comedy Central. Bill produced the Whitney Museum-featured Hip Hop documentary film Battle Sounds.  He has appeared in numerous documentaries, including VH1's And You Don't Stop, Netflix's Hip Hop Evolution, and the ABC/Hulu film Set the Record Straight: The Jam Master Jay Case.
 


 Tommy Walker (Producer) is an esteemed producer of documentary film and television who has devoted his life to stories about race and identity.  His most recent film was Toni Morrison: The Pieces I Am, an artful and intimate meditation on the legendary Nobel Laureate and Pulitzer Prize-winning author.  He co-directed and produced the feature length theatrical documentary God Grew Tired of Us, which won Best Documentary and the Audience Award at Sundance Film Festival.  He has produced 13 films for The List series, including three episodes of The Black List for HBO.  Tommy’s other titles include Mandela in America, Tutu and Franklin - A Journey towards Peace, and With All Deliberate Speed.
 

​


YoNasDa Lone Wolf (Consulting Producer) , Oglala Lakota/African American, is a human rights activist/national organizer, public speaker, rap artist, and author. Using entertainment to bring awareness to the conditions of oppressed people, YoNasDa has released two albums and toured with Wu-Tang Clan. She has organized in cities from Phoenix, AZ, to Baltimore, MD, and created #BMoreYouthRise and the National Stop the Killing rallies and marches. A former radio show host, she is a frequent guest on Power 105’s The Breakfast Club. YoNasDa spearheaded fundraising efforts for Standing Rock, Haiti, Flint, and others. She was on the executive planning committee and was co-convener of the 20th Anniversary of the Million Man March-Justice or Else!, and was a national co-convener of the Women’s March. A newspaper columnist and book author, YoNasDa is currently producing a docuseries.
 


Gary Cohen (Executive Producer) and his company, Triple Threat TV, are best known as the leading outside producers of ESPN’s 30 for 30 films, having won both a Peabody and an Emmy Award for their role on the series.  Among the 11 films Triple Threat has produced for ESPN is Catching Hell, directed by Academy Award-winner Alex Gibney.  Another two-hour special for ESPN was Requiem for the Big East (directed by Ezra Edelman), which aired in the coveted time slot directly after Selection Sunday.  Other titles include Small Potatoes: Who Killed the USFL?, Playing for the Mob, The Real Rocky, Youngstown Boys, and Believeland. Recent titles include Women of Troy (HBO), Foreman (Universal), Finding Giannis (TNT), and Born Strong (Netflix). Gary and Triple Threat also produced 10 episodes of MTV’s Award-winning series True Life and the acclaimed series Pot Barons of Colorado for MSNBC.
 


Shannon Kring (Executive Producer) is an Emmy-winning producer/director/writer who amplifies the experiences of those left vulnerable and voiceless through years of systematic oppression. Her work has been presented by numerous governments, broadcasters, and institutions including the UN Permanent Forum on Indigenous Issues, the Smithsonian Institution Museum of the American Indian, NASA, and MIT. Shannon works with the UN, US Department of State, and others concerning Indigenous rights, cultural preservation, and environmental sustainability. She is a UNWTO liaison and Honduras’ Official Goodwill Ambassador. After living in places as diverse as Helsinki and San Pedro Sula, Honduras (then the Murder Capital of the World), Shannon returned to the US to begin production on End of the Line: The Women of Standing Rock (Yle/Fuse/Al Jazeera English/NBC Universal). 



1. Contribute what you can. 

2. Spread the word. Send everyone you know the link to our Indiegogo campaign: https://igg.me/at/phillyonfire.

3. Like us on Facebook. https://wwwfacebook.com/phillyonfire.

This means without the outside influence of studio heads, network executives, or advertisers. This is where you come in.No contribution is too small. Every amount helps.We used our own funds to shoot this film in its entirety. Now we need your help to finish it.Post-Production includes assembling and editing the footage we captured, designing compelling graphics, creating a soundtrack, audio engineering, and color correction.Marketing includes getting PHILLY ON FIRE out into the world: packaging the finished film and submitting it to film festivals, broadcasters, and reviewers. It also includes social media outreach.Archival refers to the news footage we have to license for use in our film. Seeing is believing. Our story cannot be told without it. As an expression of our gratitude, we continue to update our donation perks. Please check out what's available today.Perks are offered worldwide. If you'd like, you can donate without collecting a perk, or you can gift your perk to someone else. Ross Hockrow (Director) is a rising star in the documentary world, bringing his myriad filmmaking skills to a range of projects.  PHILLY ON FIRE is his latest effort, on which he is credited as director, DP, and editor.  He filled the same roles for Born Strong (Netflix) and Finding Giannis (TNT).  It was his work as a pioneer of DSLR filmmaking that led to a series of international tours teaching visual aesthetics.  Later, he wrote a book on visual storytelling theory and then led another teaching tour on editing techniques.  Hockrow’s other documentary films include The Fieldhouse (Discovery+), Valley of Sin (Fox), Women of Troy (HBO), We Town (Sports Illustrated/Amazon), Foreman (Epix/NBC Universal), An Act of Love (Apple), and Pot Barons of Colorado (MSNBC).  Previously, he wrote, directed, and edited scripted films. Ross is currently editing an independent feature documentary on Colin Kaepernick.    Bill Stephney (Producer) served as the chief executive for the firms Def Jam Recordings (which he helped develop into a multi-billion-dollar, youth lifestyle company), SOUL Records, and Stepsun Music. He produced artists ranging from Rock-And-Roll Hall of Fame Inductee Public Enemy to singer/actress Vanessa Williams. Bill has supervised music production for films including Boomerang, Be Be’s Kids, CB4, Clockers, and Shaft. He has worked as a media consultant and advisor for ESPN, Newark Venture Partners, National Public Radio, the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, MTV Networks, Miramax Pictures, USA Networks, and Comedy Central. Bill produced the Whitney Museum-featured Hip Hop documentary film Battle Sounds.  He has appeared in numerous documentaries, including VH1's And You Don't Stop, Netflix's Hip Hop Evolution, and the ABC/Hulu film Set the Record Straight: The Jam Master Jay Case.  Tommy Walker (Producer) is an esteemed producer of documentary film and television who has devoted his life to stories about race and identity.  His most recent film was Toni Morrison: The Pieces I Am, an artful and intimate meditation on the legendary Nobel Laureate and Pulitzer Prize-winning author.  He co-directed and produced the feature length theatrical documentary God Grew Tired of Us, which won Best Documentary and the Audience Award at Sundance Film Festival.  He has produced 13 films for The List series, including three episodes of The Black List for HBO.  Tommy’s other titles include Mandela in America, Tutu and Franklin - A Journey towards Peace, and With All Deliberate Speed. ​YoNasDa Lone Wolf (Consulting Producer) , Oglala Lakota/African American, is a human rights activist/national organizer, public speaker, rap artist, and author. Using entertainment to bring awareness to the conditions of oppressed people, YoNasDa has released two albums and toured with Wu-Tang Clan. She has organized in cities from Phoenix, AZ, to Baltimore, MD, and created #BMoreYouthRise and the National Stop the Killing rallies and marches. A former radio show host, she is a frequent guest on Power 105’s The Breakfast Club. YoNasDa spearheaded fundraising efforts for Standing Rock, Haiti, Flint, and others. She was on the executive planning committee and was co-convener of the 20th Anniversary of the Million Man March-Justice or Else!, and was a national co-convener of the Women’s March. A newspaper columnist and book author, YoNasDa is currently producing a docuseries. Gary Cohen (Executive Producer) and his company, Triple Threat TV, are best known as the leading outside producers of ESPN’s 30 for 30 films, having won both a Peabody and an Emmy Award for their role on the series.  Among the 11 films Triple Threat has produced for ESPN is Catching Hell, directed by Academy Award-winner Alex Gibney.  Another two-hour special for ESPN was Requiem for the Big East (directed by Ezra Edelman), which aired in the coveted time slot directly after Selection Sunday.  Other titles include Small Potatoes: Who Killed the USFL?, Playing for the Mob, The Real Rocky, Youngstown Boys, and Believeland. Recent titles include Women of Troy (HBO), Foreman (Universal), Finding Giannis (TNT), and Born Strong (Netflix). Gary and Triple Threat also produced 10 episodes of MTV’s Award-winning series True Life and the acclaimed series Pot Barons of Colorado for MSNBC. Shannon Kring (Executive Producer) is an Emmy-winning producer/director/writer who amplifies the experiences of those left vulnerable and voiceless through years of systematic oppression. Her work has been presented by numerous governments, broadcasters, and institutions including the UN Permanent Forum on Indigenous Issues, the Smithsonian Institution Museum of the American Indian, NASA, and MIT. Shannon works with the UN, US Department of State, and others concerning Indigenous rights, cultural preservation, and environmental sustainability. She is a UNWTO liaison and Honduras’ Official Goodwill Ambassador. After living in places as diverse as Helsinki and San Pedro Sula, Honduras (then the Murder Capital of the World), Shannon returned to the US to begin production on End of the Line: The Women of Standing Rock (Yle/Fuse/Al Jazeera English/NBC Universal). 1. Contribute what you can. 2. Spread the word. Send everyone you know the link to our Indiegogo campaign: https://igg.me/at/phillyonfire.3. Like us on Facebook. https://wwwfacebook.com/phillyonfire.

story:
There's still time to...

BE IN THE FILM!   

OWN A PIECE OF THE FILM!

AND BE A PRODUCER!

 

That's Right!

The majority of CULT OF BLOOD is FINISHED!

 

 

We are RAISING FUNDS to get TWO Celebrity Cameos and pay for post-production costs!

This is EXCITING because YOU still have a chance to BE IN THE MOVIE and/or OWN A PIECE from an iconic scene from the film!

 

DAVE SHERIDAN AS TODD:

FELISSA ROSE AS CRYSTAL:

NADIA WHITE AS PRINCESS JILL KOREK:

 

WE'RE LOOKING TO GET TWO BIG NAMES FROM THE HORROR AND COMEDY COMMUNITY FOR CAMEO PARTS!

THE MORE WE RAISE THE WEIRDER WE CAN GET!

THE REMAINING FUNDS WILL TOWARDS FUN SONG CREDITS!

GOOD MUSIC CAN BE VERY EXPENSIVE!

LET'S ROCK AND ROLL! AND...

JOIN US! 

"MEMBERSHIP IS FREE, BUT THE DUES ARE KILLER"

story:
Story

Sugarcoat is a short film inspired by a true story. In the film, the Tanaka family gathers to celebrate the 3rd birthday of their youngest child, Mae. Naomi, her mother, is drinking at the dinner table and Peter, Naomi's husband, is disappointed and tries to stray the family's attention away from her. Dinner is served by Naomi's parents and as the night goes on, tensions grow higher. Kyle, the couple's teenage son, grows tired of their sugarcoating and leaves the room, forcing Naomi to admit that she is unhappy. Her parents are lost as to why, but now all cards are on the table. Reluctantly, Peter must take responsibility for his part in the pain she has been feeling--he must confess what they have known for some time...he is a gay man. Despite the shock, Jichan and Bachan try to comfort Naomi and explain to her that in the end, family is all that matters.

Why is this Important?

This story highlights those who have struggled with their sexuality and were not able to find their voices earlier in life. It shows the consequences of repressing your true self and gives a visual representation of how families deal with intergenerational trauma. Above all, it demonstrates how love comes in all forms and the importance of family.

The Team

Screen Director/Writer: Julia Borges Bertassoli

Director of Talent Relations: Hau'oli Carr

Producer: Destiny Golden

Director of Photography: Christopher Medina

Production Designer: James Donoghue

Editor: Caden Cerulle

Composer: Alan Perales

Assistant Production Designer: Aubrey Paul

We are all friends and students in the Television, Film, and New Media Production major at San Diego State University. We're so excited to be finally be working on our senior thesis film after the uncertainty of this past year. We want to make this project the best it can be and we would love your help to make that happen!

Where are your donations going?

All donations are greatly appreciated and will go towards making this film happen. The money we raise will help us afford:

- Set dressing

- Talent (including salary, hair, makeup, and transportation)

- Studio teacher for the child actor

- Equipment and paperwork

- Catering

All money leftover will go towards festival entry fees and movie promotion.

As college students, we really appreciate any financial help we can get to fulfill our college goals and start our professional careers! THANK YOU!

story:
Who We Are:

 

Hi! I’m Nathalie Kane, Writer, Producer and Co-Director of Tokyo in NYC. 

  • While Tokyo in NYC short film followed a Japanese man finding creative ways to enamor his Haitian love interest at the height of a pandemic, we want to bring the feature film to life, exploring the relationship highs and lows between two people from different cultural backgrounds. We will join them on their journey of realizing their inner patience and capacity for love and understanding in a world that may not be as ready to embrace them as they once thought.

 

What We Need & What You Get

You will be helping provide:

  • LOCATIONS

        - We want you to feel the NYC experience by bringing you t some of our favorite locations while      still telling an exuberant story.

  • CAST

          Besides our Lead Cast, we will have featured background actors, Day players and background.

  • Crew including (but not limited to): -

            - Director

            - Assistant Director

            - 1st AD

            - 2nd AD

            - Key lighting

            - Audio

            - Grip

            - Gaffer

            - Production Assistants

           - Interns

            - Behind the scenes Photographers

       More Crew to Ensure Everyone’s Safety!

            - COVID-19 Health and Safety Officers

              - Set Paramedics

              - Stunt Coordinator

              - Intimacy Coordinator

 

  • POST PRODUCTION

Post production means having the best editors, colorists,  social media managers and promoters to bring the best story possible to light. We’ll also need to cover distribution.

 

Each contribution means something special. That is why, no matter what your contribution is, you receive a special gift from us!

 

 

The Impact

I couldn’t have known at the time of writing this beautiful story that so much hate could be reintroduced into the world. The #StopAsianhate movement arose recently after countless unprovoked violent encounters against members of the Asian community occurred nationwide. Black people, knowing all too well how this feels came together in support of the Asian community to help heal and find a solution.
 

Tokyo in NYC is not just a movie but a bridge, an opportunity for people to experience that love transcends all boundaries and ore conceived notions. 
 

In the film festival run, our  Short Film has won Best Comedy at Canadian Diversity Film Festival, Best Original Story at Oniros Film Awards, and has been Finalist and Officially Selected for many other film festivals. 

Risks & Challenges

Our main hurdle is amassing the right amount of capital that it would take to deliver our story in the best possible way to you.  With COVID-19 still roaring, we need to confidently say that our  cast and crew was well paid and well fed. Locations also weigh in a considerable amount, and being that we are in NYC , we want you to see and feel that New York City is back!

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Get the word out and make some noise about our campaign. Share on social media; Facebook, Instagram, tiktok, Twitter, Tumblr, Weebo etc.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
Short Summary

Hi there!  Thanks for stopping by our page!  We are Slade Wolfe Enterprises.  She is Lexi Wolfe - award-winning actress and writer - and he is Andrew Slade - with nearly 30 years experience in theatre, film and TV.  We're both PROUDLY NEURODIVERSE - aside other conditions, we both have ADHD, which is why this project is so important to us both.  Oh, and Our Brains really Can't Sit Still - which is why we're asking you to get involved!

While everyone has heard of ADHD,  it's still very misunderstood among most people - the stereotype of the hyperactive boy running and throwing things around still pervades, even though that's only one type of the condition.  The affect of ADHD in adults is not understood in the general consciousness at all.  In the UK alone it's estimated that over 4% of the adult population have ADHD - but as only 120,000 adults have been diagnosed (less that 10% of that 4%) the number could be much greater!

People with ADHD as adults are more likely to suffer from other mental health problems if their ADHD goes undiagnosed, as they struggle to deal with all the different things life can throw at you.

We're very proud to be working with Europe's largest user-led ADHD charity, The ADHD Foundation.

They are providing us with the latest statistics and research into the condition, and they will have use of the final film as an educational tool to help people understand more about what life with ADHD can be like for an adult.

While we have other funding already coming to the project, by supporting us you can help us get to work early on the pre-production elements of the shoot, which will help the shoot itself be more organised (critical for people with ADHD!), streamlined and overall better quality.

By supporting us you can help us get out a stronger message to educate and encourage people out there who think there is something wrong with them to see that they are capable, and talented, and that there are things out there they can do, and help to be found.  By supporting us, you will help giving hope to others.  What more precious gift is there, than to know you've been able to help another human being?

 

What We Need & What You Get

We have set ourselves £3,000 as the target for this campaign.  That will be enough for us to focus full-time on script development, sourcing and paying for our locations, securing our cameraman and Director of Photography (we're hoping to work with the DOP we used for an international film project we shot during lockdown last year called The Night Time World (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt3631242/)), and our sound engineer, to enable us to plan and plot the shoot so we can get the look and tone right when we go into filming.

Additional funds will be used to start on marketing and distribution efforts.  We're currently looking at a number of different film festivals, as well as agreements with alternative distributors who have interest in educational films like MBCSS.

Because choice is an issue for a lot of folks with ADHD, we've decided to keep our back rewards quite simple! So....

£5 - get's you a thanks shout out on social media

£10 - get's you a shoutout and a digital copy of the film on completion

£25 - gets you the above and some photos from the production exclusively for you

£50 - gets you the above and a signed copy of the script (sent out when the film has been released)

£75 - gets you the above and an original poem written for you by Lexi

£100 - gets you the above and a video message from set by a member of the team

£150 - gets you the above, plus an associate producer credit on IMDb

£500 - gets the above, but the associate producer credit is upgraded to co-producer!

£3,000 - gets the above, but co-producer credit upgraded to Executive Producer

If we don't make it to our target, then all is not lost!  We will use what money we do get to fund our further development of the project, and to help us raise additional funds to meet the shortfall.  If we are close to the target, then we should be able to use that to pay our desired crew members to be able to have some pre-production planning meetings to prepare for the shoot.  Any money raised at this point helps us to be able to focus more time on the film, and less time finding alternative income streams.

The Impact

Mental health is still poorly funded, and generally poorly communicated with people.  The purpose of films like this is the ability to communicate and show people the reality of living with certain conditions.  By making people more aware of symptoms, we hope to help make them more aware of their own conditions, and those of their friends.  We hope that people, by understanding ADHD better, will be able to seek their own diagnosis and by doing so, get the help and support they need to live their best possible lives.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you're not able to donate (and even if you can) there are still ways you can support us.  Please share our campaign on social media, or with your contacts via email, WhatsApp, or any other means of communication.  You never know, you could end up making a difference to someone's life that you care about.

 

Thank you for reading about our passion project.  We hope that one day in the not too distant future you'll be able to see the fruits of our work.
